DIV1.P: MAR-PLOT; Or The Second Part of The BUSIE-BODY. A COMEDY. As it is Acted at the THEATRE-ROYAL in Drury-Lane, BY Her MAJESTY's Servants.
LONDON: Printed for Jacob Tonson at Shakespear's Head over-against Catherine-street in the Strand. 1711.

DIV1.HEAD: TO THE RIGHT HONOURABLE HENRY BENTINCK, EARL of Portland, Viscount Woodstock, Baron of Cirencester, Captain of Her Majesty's First Troop of Guards, &c.
DIV1.P:
WOmen, and Men like Women, natu∣rally fly to the Brave for Protection. This Pretence Mar-plot and I have for Ad∣dressing to your LORDSHIP. We know it is the peculiar Distinction of Noble Minds, that they are ready to receive under their
Care the Distress'd, though they have no other Merit, than that they beseech their Patronage.

When I say this, my LORD, I wou'd not be understood to conceal, that my Play has been very kindly receiv'd; but we Wo∣men overlook all Praise, but from those Persons whose Approbation we most esteem. We are apt to be carry'd away from Admi∣rers to those we Admire: And this Come∣dy prefers the Honour of being thrown at Your Feet, to the Applause of an Audience. It is the Misfortune of our Sex, that we are deterr'd from the Advantages of a Learn∣ed Education: But as our Expressions are Artless, our Sentiments are less Disguis'd. Had I, my LORD, the Skill of a Writer, I shou'd here record your Noble Father's Zeal for his Royal Master, and celebrate that Care and Fidelity which preserv'd the Life of Our Deliverer: But, instead of men∣tioning this Obligation, which my late Lord Portland laid on every Man in England, I confine my self to what we owe Him for being your Father.

That Your LORDSHIP may long bless the World with the same Virtues which You have shown in the Entrance You have made on the busie Stage of it, and long en∣joy the Advantages of an Affluent Fortune, Graceful Person, and Generous Mind, is the ardent Prayer of,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Lordship's most Devoted, most Obedient, Humble Servant, SUSANNA CENTLIVRE.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE.
DIV1.L: THE Men of Wit do now their Brains fatigue
So much with Politicks and State-Intrigue!
That there's not one Male-Poet of the Age
Will condescend to labour for the Stage.
Therefore our Author, tho' no Rules she knows,
What Nature prompts, with Artless Hand bestows:
You'll see the Subject for the Genius fit,
A Busie-Body, drawn by Female Wit,
Still on the Hunt to know of others Wooing,
Eternally employ'd, and nothing doing!
Into dear Secrets anxiously they press,
Destroying, even where they wish Success!
The scanty Age all better Fare denies,
And no new Characters the Town supplies.
Some Years ago Wit had a larger Field,
And every Room cou'd fresh Stage-Coxcombs yield;
But long has been all Humorous Folly crost,
All Fool in empty Politician's lost.
Scowrers, and Rakes, and Debauchees are o'er,
Beaux are extinct, and Bullies are no more.
Therefore in Scarcity of home-bred Tools,
Your Treat to Night's compos'd of Foreign Fools;
And tho' our Mar-plot has been shown before,
The Fool may differ, on a different Shore—
For once, then, break old Custom; be not o'er-nice,
But let the self-same Woman please you Twice.

DIV1.HEAD: Dramatis Personae.

LIST.HEAD: MEN.
LIST.LABEL: Don Lopez, a Noble Portuguese, Brother to Dona Perriera.
Don Perriera, a rich Merchant.
Colonel Ravelin, An English Officer.
Charles Gripe, Come to Lisbon about his Fa∣ther-in-Law's Effects who is dead, and left him Executor.
Mar-plot, Went over with him to see the Country.
Lorenzo.

LIST.HEAD: WOMEN.
LIST.LABEL: Dona Perriera, Wife to Don Perriera, in love with Charles.
Isabinda, Wife to Charles, follows him in Boys Clothes.
Mademoisel Joneton, an affected French Lady residing in Lisbon.
Marton, Her Sister, in Love with Colonel Ravelin.
Margaritta.

DIV1.STAGE: The SCENE the Terriera de Passa in Lisbon.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE I.

HEAD.STAGE: SCENE, The Terriera de Passa in Lisbon.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Don Lopez, and Don Perriera.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: WHY Brother, you are distracted; how often have you fill'd my Brain with these Chyme∣ra's? Why should I murder my Wife with∣out a Cause?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Lop.
SP.P: A Cause! Do's a Cuckold want a Cause?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Per.
SP.P: Look ye, Senior, keep that Word Cuckold between your Teeth, till you can prove me such, or by St. Anthony you shall feel what Mettle my Spado is made of. [Laying his Hand to his Sword.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Lop.
SP.P: Name your Spado again, and I'll shake thee into Dust, thou feeble Dotard. Your Spado! employ it against the Man that robs you of your Honour, and not against him that would preserve it. I say, My Sister, your Wife, is a Strumpet, the Strumpet of a damn'd Heretick: I saw the Looks, nay the Signs, she gave some of the English Officers, as she came from Church this Morning.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Per.
SP.P: English Officers!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Lop.
SP.P:
English I'm sure they were, I can't swear they were all Officers, nor cou'd I perceive which she sign'd to, or he shou'd not live to meet her Wishes—Now if you don't like the Name of Cuckold, find another for the Husband of a Whore, if you can—For my part I know of none; but this I know, if you won't punish her as a Wife, I will as a Sister; she shall not stain
the Honour of my House this way; she injur'd it too much in marrying you. I shall pursue my own Method, and so Fare∣well. [Going.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Per.
SP.P: So, there's the Blessing of matching into an ho∣nourable Family: Now must I bear all Affronts patiently, be∣cause I'm but a Merchant, forsooth—Oh, give me any Curse but this—Pray, Senior, give me leave to speak one Word with you: I am convinc'd of my too much Indulgence for this very Cockatrice, and there remains nothing to quicken my Re∣venge, but certain Demonstration.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Lop.
SP.P: Certain Demonstration! Must you have Ocular Proof? Must your Coward Heart be animated with the Sight? A Curse of your Equivocations—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Per.
SP.P: No, any other Sense will serve; let me hear 'em, feel 'em, nay, smell 'em; and sure Cuckoldom is so rank a Scent, that, tho' I liv'd in England, where they scarce breathe any other Air, I cou'd distinguish it.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Lop.
SP.P: Now you talk like a Portuguese; keep up this Pas∣sion, and secure the Honour of your House and mine, and deserve the Alliance of my Blood, it shall be my Care to fix them.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Per.
SP.P: And when they are so, mine to execute.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Colonel Ravelin!

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Charles Gripe! honest Charles, how dost thou do, Boy? Why, what brought thee to Lisbon?

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Part of the Cause that brought you, Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: What? art thou in the Army?

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: No, Colonel, I leave Honour to you, Interest brought me.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: They are Twin-Brothers, Charles; if Interest did not drive, Honour wou'd come slowly on: Art thou turn'd Mer∣chant then?

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: No, faith, not I; but it pleas'd Heav'n to take my Wife's Father out of the way, who left me Executor, and his Concerns here oblig'd me to take this Voyage.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: So then, old Sir, jealous Traffick is dead at last. How long do you intend to stay?

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P:
Longer than I expected when I embark'd: I came away in such a Hurry, the Ship sailing sooner than I thought she
wou'd, I forgot to put up some Papers, without which I can't adjust my Accounts with some Merchants here; I have writ to my Wife to send them.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: That was very unlucky; prithee, how dost thou spend thy Time?

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Why very insipidly: How do you pass yours? What Company have you here?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: All sorts; the Women, I'll say that for 'em, are kind enough, and won't put you to the Expence of Swearing and Lying to gain them; but a Man is as safe in an Engagement, as in their Arms; Fortune is the kind Friend in both the On∣sets: But I have got acquainted in a French Family, which are not altogether so dangerous one way, but much more so ano∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Ay! how's that, Colonel?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Why, I'm fearful of dwindling into an honourable A∣mour there.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Exert your Gallantry, gain your Point once, and those Fears will vanish. The French Ladies are easie of Access.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Right, the French Gayety resembles the English Com∣plaisance, yet they have always a Reserve to dash your Ex∣pectations, and when you think your self in a manner Master of their Cover'd-way, they spring a Mine of Coquetry, and blow you up at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Say you so, Colonel? Why then give me the Lisbon Dames, that surrender to the Bold and Brave: He deserves not a Woman, that would not run some Hazard, provided she be kind.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Some are of Opinion, that the jilting Fair gives the surest Blow, and Sucklin says, 'Tis Expectation makes the Blessing dear. This French Woman has found the way to unite my jarring Inclinations, and tune 'em to the pitch of Constancy, and I am very apprehensive of becoming that tame Monster, call'd a Husband. Ah! I find I am caught, for I can name that terrible Word without starting.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! I shall have you in my Class: Sure the La∣dy that can make such an entire Conquest over your Heart must be a Person of extraordinary Parts, Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P:
Yes, faith, her Ladyship has very extraordinary Parts; she's airy to Affectation, and changeable as the Wind: She has
Tongue enough for a Lawyer, but as hard to be understood as an Apothecary: She begins as many Stories as a Romance, and ends them as intricately, or, to speak more properly, seldom ends them at all: She's as whimsical as a Projector, as obstinate as a Physician, and as faithful as the Monarch of her Country.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Admirable Qualities for a Wife; and can you forsake the whole Sex for this Woman?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Humph! that I won't swear; but I find I can't forsake her for the whole Sex: To be plain with you, I have try'd the Strength of Variety, and at this time am in prospect of the Fa∣vour from as fine a Woman as any in Lisbon; yet this Medly of Womankind triumphs over all, and in the midst of my Rap∣tures I murmur Joneton.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: But may I not see this wondrous Engineer, who can countermine her whole Sex, and blow up the Magazine of your Affections, Colonel?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: You shall, but you must give me your Honour not to rival me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: The Description you have given, Colonel, secures you from that Fear; besides, you know I am marry'd, neither am I destitute of a Mistress, tho' in a strange Place. I this Morning was a assur'd, by a Sign from a Lady's Hankerchief, that my Wants shou'd be supply'd upon Occasion. I did not rightly understand her, till the good old Duena explain'd her Mean∣ing; and this Night I shall be happy in her Arms.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: You are a Stranger to these Affairs Charles, take heed, proceed with caution, for the Women here are as warm in their Revenge as in their Inclinations, bare Suspicion justifies Murder; if you manage your Intreague so closely to escape the Husband and Relations, 'tis odds but your Mistress finds some pretence to employ her Bravoes, Fellows that will dispatch a dozen Men for a Moydre.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P:
I go well arm'd, understand the Language, and will not easily fall a Victime, but resolve to see the event of this In∣treague; the old Matron told me that the Lady was young and beautiful, her Husband a Merchant, rich, covetous, old, and ugly; that she hated him worse than Penance, and lov'd me bet∣ter than her Prayers; shall I be such a Poultroon to decline a Lady's Summons? No, for the honour of Britain, it shall never be said an Englishman fled either from the Wars of Mars, or
Venus; let her bring me on, if I discharge not my self with Honour, and make my Retreat secure, may I forfeit the Embraces of the Sex.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Well said Charles, in my Conscience you married Men encroach too much upon our Prerogative methinks; you who purchase pleasure by way of Annuity, should leave us Batchel∣lours the liberty of the Freehold.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: The Ground we course in, is never the worse for your Use.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: No, 'tis sometimes the better; there's many a Wife lies Fallow, and many a good Estate wou'd want an Heir, if it were not for us young Fellows, especially Soldiers.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: I think you ought to make Provision for the Recruits you raise, as much as for your Widows, they are far more Nu∣merous.
SP.STAGE: [A noise of clashing of Swords, and Murder cry'd within.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Ha! What noise is that?

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: 'Tis Mar-plot's Voice, his damn'd Curiosity has brought him into some Mischief, I'll lay my Life on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: The Devil's in that Fellow; what made you bring him with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Murder, murder, [Mar. running pursued by two Bravoes. Ah Charles, help me dear Charles, for Heav'ns sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: A Curse on your Paper Skull, what have you been doing now?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Nothing at all, as I hope to be saved; only I had a mind to see where that Lady liv'd that shook her Handkerchief at you, and out of no other design than to inform you, I protest, Charles, when immediately these two Scoundrels came slap upon me, I know no more for what than the Child that's unborn; but I'm sure I shall feel their blows this Month, pox take 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: For what? Why you took the only method in the World to have your Guts let out: Ha, ha! watch a Woman in Lisbon! Hark you young Gentleman, suppress that natural Curiosity of diving into other Peoples Affairs, or never hope to see old Eng∣land again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I wish I were safe in it, Colonel Ravelin! The duce take me if I saw you before, my Senses was all in such a hurry, with these unconscionable Villains, that—

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: That you over-look'd your Friends, I warrant.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: You have said it Charles, but I hope the Colonel will forgive me.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: To be plain with you, Mr. Mar-plot, I shall take these kind of Over-sights for particular Favours, if you don't shake off that Temper of yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Pish, prethee Colonel don't put on those grave Airs, why what harm is there in't?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: There's ill Manners in't, I'm sure, and have a care you han't your Bones broke for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Look ye Mar-plot, you must either resolve to quit this inquisitive Humour, or forfeit my Acquaintance,

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: A Man may be ruin'd by your foolish Quarrels.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Upon my Soul, Colonel, I never quarrel'd with any Man, out of design to hurt him in my Life: Charles can witness for me, that I hate fighting.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: So can every Body else that knows you; I wish you hated Impertinence as much, for the good of Society.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Well, you of all Men living have the least reason to complain; I have run the hazard of my Life many a time for you, and in my Conscience I believe I shall fall your Martyr one time or another.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Your own you mean, you'll certainly be Canoniz'd by all the Busie-body's about Town.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Is this all the thanks I get for my Friendship? Well Charles, well, you shall see I can prefer Safety, and sacrifice my Curiosity too, as you call it.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: That's the way to oblige your Friends, Mr. Mar-plot, ne∣ver desire to know more than they are willing to tell you, readily comply with a reasonable Demand, and never meddle with any body's Business but your own, this will render you agreeable to all Companies.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ay! But that will make all Companies very disagree∣able to me. (Aside.) But Colonel, is there nothing due from one Friend to another? One ought to be let into the bosom Secrets of a Friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Not always, for there are some Secrets of such a Nature that will not admit of that Freedom; for Example, suppose your Friend had an Affair with another Man's Wife, or Daughter, where's the advantage of your knowing it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Why I wou'd watch the Husband or Father in the mean time, prevent his being surpriz'd, and perhaps save his Life.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: But how wou'd you save his Honour? A Man of Ho∣nour must have no Confidents in those Cases.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Then hang Honour, I say, 'tis good for nothing but to spoil Conversation. Shall I beg a pinch of your Snuff, Colonel?

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Colonel Ravelin's Servant with a Letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: With all my Heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: The Messenger stays for your Answer, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: A Letter! Wou'd I were a Fly now, that I might swop down upon the Paper, and read it before his Face: Lord, Lord, what wou'd I give for an universal Knowledge? [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Tell the Messenger I'll observe Orders to a second

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Orders! Why, what have you Orders to march, Colonel?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: From this place I have, Sir. Charles, I'd be glad to drink a Bottle with you and Mr. Mar-plot in the Evening at my Lodg∣ings: There's the Directions.
SP.STAGE: [Tears the Superscription of a Letter, and gives Charles.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I'll wait on you home Colonel, that I may know the House again exactly.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Excuse me Sir, I'm not going home perhaps. Charles, I'll expect you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: I'll do my self the honour to wait on you; adieu.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Perhaps! but perhaps I won't believe you: He has a world of Manners to a Gentleman in a strange Place, I'll be sworn; ha! Charles's gone, nay, then I have a rare opportuni∣ty, egad he has forgot his Snuff-Box, an excellent Excuse to follow him; the Devil take his Letter for me, it has given me the Cholick.

HEAD.STAGE: SCENE, A Chamber in Don Perriera's House.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Are you sure the Englishman will come? What said he?

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: He swer'd me in Transport, I warrant him a Man every inch of him Come, Seniora? Yes, yes, he'll come, tho' a thousand Dangers threatned him; these Englishmen are brave Fellows, if they were not Hereticks.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: If he has but the Faith of a Lover, no matter for his Religion Margaritta; but what came of the busie Fellow that watch'd us? Did you obey my Orders?

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Yes marry did I, and the Bravo's assur'd me they had taught him to look another way for the future.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: They dispatch'd him, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: No, he was rescu'd, upon the Terriera de Passa.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Ill Fate; he did not see where I enter'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: No, no, Madam, you are safe; hush, here's my Ma∣ster Don Perriera.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Then there's my Jaylor: This Englishman runs in my Head so much, that methinks I hate the Sight of my Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: So, you have been at Church to Day, my Dear, have you not?

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Yes, my Dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: And who did you see there, Wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Do you think I pass my Time in Observation at Church, my Dear? I hope I have other Business to do there.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: And you are basely bely'd, if you have not other Business to do elsewhere too, Wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: What do you mean, my Dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Nay, ask your Brother Don Lopez, who will have it that you send your Eyes a mrroding for English Forage; my Dear, have a care of an Ambuscade; for the whole Artil∣lery of his Senses are drawn down upon you, and Jealousie leads the Force of his Invention; and though I love you, Wife, yet if his Spies bring certain Intelligece of your holding Correspondence with those Heretick Dogs, the English Of∣ficers, I shall infallibly treat you like a Traitress to your Lord and Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Ha! I fear I'm betray'd. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: My Lady a Traitress to her Lord and Husband! Don Lopez is a Traitor to his own Flesh and Blood for saying so, by my Virginity—

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Away, away; that's so stale an Oath, 'twill not be credited.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P:
The Accusation's false, I do not know one English Officer in Lisbon, by this sacred Sign; [crosses her Thumb and Finger, and kisses it.] For my Duena assures me my Lover is no
Officer; so far I'm not forsworn. [Aside.] I thought, my Dear had promis'd me never more to mind the Insinuations of that cruel Brother; his Prejudice is founded on our Marriage, his proud imperious Temper scorns your Alliance, and racks his Soul to find a Cause to ruin you: And must it be by blasting of my Fame? Will not my Life suffice? And dares he not employ his own Hand? But wou'd he make you guilty of my Murther? oh barbarous inhumane Thought!

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Cruel Don Lopez, now do I wish I may die a Maid; a terrible Wish, were I not out of Danger of the Curse falling upon me; if I believe my Lady ever thought of any Man but your self, Senior. Poor Creature, I'm sure her Heart is full of Fears about you when you are absent.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Ay, lest I shou'd come back before she'd have me.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: He is the Devil of a Guesser. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Unkindly urg'd, Deary; I'm sure, by my own Consent, I wou'd never have you—

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: In your Sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: The Man is certainly a Witch. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Out of my sight, I meant, Deary.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: That wou'd be as bad on the other side.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: For my part, Deary, I'm never happier than when thou art in my Arms, and cou'd be content to have thee always there.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Yes, I shou'd have a fine Life truly, to be always in your Arms.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Look ye there now, the Dog in the Manger.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: What wou'd you have me say, my Dear, to con∣vince you of my Love?

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Look ye, Wife, 'tis no matter what you say, do but take care what you do: No regaling your Pallate with Fo∣reign Dishes, they are very dangerous. Take my Word for't, you'll live longer upon your own Food, and with less Danger of your Health.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Nay, if Diseases are prevented by dry Meats, he's in the right on't. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: I know not what you'd have me say, my Dear; but if you think me false, confine me to my Chamber, or send me to a Monastery. Grant, Heav'n, he do's not take me at my Word. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: I wou'd not give a Crusada for my Place, if he shou'd; a cloyster'd Mistress brings no Grise to the Servant's Mill. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Sure Don Lopez do's belye her; I always found her thus pliable, kind, and modest; however, I'll watch her narrowly. In the mean time, to take off her Suspicion, I'll seem to believe her.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: So, all's right once more, I see by that Ogle of his. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Come, my Love, dry thy Eyes; I am not jealous, nor shall thy Brother make me so; I'll be an Englishman to thee. Come, buss thy own Husband then, do Deary.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: That Buss secures me a Moydre before I sleep, for the English are the most generous Men living in their Love Affairs. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: And won't you be jealous of me no more indeed, and indeed, nor let that naughty Brother vex you, till you fright me out of my Wits again? Will you promise me that?

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Yes indeed, and indeed, I will, you little coaxing Thief you. By St. Anthony, thou dost look wondrous handsome methinks. Od! if I were not to meet some Merchants about Busi∣ness, thou should'st to Bed this Moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: To Bed quotha? I had rather thou wert in thy Grave. [Aside.] What? then are you going to leave me, my Jewel?

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: But for two or three Hours, my Dear; and then I will so buss it, and love it, and hug it, and squeeze it.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Ah! the very Apprehension makes me sick. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: What makes my Dear sick?

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: The Duce take his Ears—The Apprehension of losing my dear, little, old Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Well turn'd. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Thou shalt quickly have me again, my Jewel.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Too soon, I dare swear. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: By Deary, go make much of thy self till I come back. Here, Seniora Margaritta, take care of your Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Yes, Senior, a better Care than you think for. Come, Madam, now prepare to receive the charming Englishman.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: I think I had better let it alone; do you consider the Hazard which I run?

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Hazard! Are you born in Portugal, and talk of Ha∣zard? Why, there is not a Woman in Lisbon that wou'd not run twice as much for such a Fellow—Do you consider the Difference between him and your old Husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Yes, and what I must suffer too, if I am caught.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Nay, nay, if Fear throws so many Bug-bears in your way, follow your own Fancy: I'm like to make a fine Penny on't truly—Pray send me of no more Fool's Errands; I'll car∣ry no more Challenges, if you do not mean to engage: I trifle my Time away sweetly.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Nay, don't be angry, Marget; 'tis not but that I have as much Inclination for that handsome Man as ever, were I sure not to be discover'd, I shou'd not alter my Resolution.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: That shall be my Care, I warrant you, Madam; he comes in by a Rope-Ladder at your Closet-window, by which he may return with Secrecy and Expedition upon the least Surprize.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: My Closet-window looks upon the River, how can he come that way?

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: By a Boat, that shall wait to receive him again.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Let him come then.

L.HI: When Inclination pleads, Fears quickly fly,
And powerful Love can Reason's Force defy.

HEAD.STAGE: SCENE changes to Colonel Ravelin's Lodgings.

DIV2.STAGE: The Colonel looking on his Watch.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: 'Tis within two Minutes of the Time; I must be pun∣ctual; for Women here forgive not the least Omission. Let me see, is my Trap-door unbolted? Not yet?
SP.STAGE: [Goes to the Chimney, and seems to pull at a Trap-door.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Here's a Gentleman to wait on you, Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: I'll see no body: Did not I tell you so, Block-head?
SP.STAGE: [Gives him a Box on the Ear.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Nay, 'tis only I, Colonel; don't be angry, you for∣got your Snuff-box, and I thought you wou'd want it, so I brought it you, that's all, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, you need not have given your self the Trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I think it no Trouble, upon my Soul, Sir. Ad! you have very pretty Lodgings here, Colonel: What a very fine Collection of Pictures you have got? Pray who is this at length, Colonel?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: I can't tell indeed, Sir; they belong to the House. Pox take this Coxcomb. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ho, do they so? Pray what do you give a Week for these Lodgings?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Prithee ask me no Questions; I don't know, I have forgot. Ha! the Door unbolts, which way shall I get rid of this Puppy? [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Hey-day! forgot! that's impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Look ye, Sir, I perceive it is impossible for me to an∣swer all the Questions you may possibly ask at this time; but in the Evening I promise to solve all your Interrogatories.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Nay, nay, Colonel, if I am troublesome, I'll be gone—This Uneasiness has a Meaning. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: You'll oblige me in so doing, Mr. Mar-plot; for I have a Visit to make this Moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Is it to Man or Woman, Colonel? Come hang it, you may tell me that.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Why then, it is to a Lady: Now I hope you'll leave me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ay, ay, with all my Heart; but I may go with you to the Door, may I not?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Go to the Devil, Sir. Death, how shall I shift him off? [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: How snappish he is—how the duce shall I manage to find out this Intrigue? [Aside.] Well, well, don't be angry Colonel: I'll leave you below Stairs,

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Confound his Impertinence. Death Sir, suppose I don't go down Stairs, how then?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: How then? Why how then do you intend to make your Visit, Colonel? You don't go out at the Window, do you?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav
SP.P: No more of your Impertinence, Sir, but be gone, or I shall fling you out at Window.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Nay, if you be so Cholerick, your humble Servant Egad I'll secure the Key, I will know the bottom of this, if I die for't.
SP.STAGE: [Snatches the Key of the Door, and puts it in his Pocket, and Exits. The Colonel slaps the Door after him, then runs to the Trap-door, pulls it up and descends, and pulls it down after him.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: This is the most intolerable Dog I ever saw: Pox take him, there's half a minute claps'd.
SP.STAGE: [Mar-plot opens the Door softly and peeps.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Egad he's not come out yet, what is he a doing? Ha! I don't see him—nor hear him neither—od, I'll venture in—upon my Soul here's no Body: Why sure he deals with the Devil—here's no Door but this that I can see—Is there any way out at Window?—No, faith, that's impossible, they have all Iron Bars.—What can be become of him? Oh! I have it now, before George he's gone up the Chimney, for there is no other Passage—it must be so, [Peeps up the Chimney] Egad the Chimney is large, and easy enough to mount, now have I a strong inclination to follow him—troth and I will too—sure the greatest pleasure in this World, ls in disco∣vering what other People take such pains to conceal—now they may call me impertinent Block head—inquisitive Fool—and ill-bred Puppy—and what they please, but I'd not quit the pleasure of knowing this Secret, for the finest breeding in France.—I'm afraid I shall spoil my Coat—rot him, what a cursed, dirty Contrivance has he found out; hold, well thought on—I'll, I'll, turn the wrong side outwards—Ay, that will do, [Turns his Coat] so now for the Art of Chimney Sweep∣ing; egad Colonel, in spight of all your caution, ten to one but I know your haunts; Lord how I shall laugh at Night, when we meet, how I will Joak upon him. Ha, ha, ha.
SP.STAGE: [Goes into the Chimney, and the Scene shuts.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE I.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: COme, Courage, Senior Englise, fear nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: I hope you have a better Opinion of my Country, Seniora, than to think me afraid; but where is the Lady? the beautiful young Lady, which you told me off, my dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: She's forth-coming, Sir—So, see what it is to be stricken in years now, he looks over me, as if I were a thing of his own Species. Well Senior, I assure you I have done you no small ser∣vice with my Lady, poor young thing, she had so many scru∣ples, but I told her a thousand things in your Favour: Seniora said I, the Cavalier is a fine Cavalier, he is—

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Oh the Devil, if this old Woman's Clack sets a going, there will be no end—I understand you Senior, pray give me leave to thank you; and to engage you more heartily in my In∣terest, be pleas'd to accept this Token of my Esteem.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Ah Seniora, you English have excellent faculties to please us Women; I'll swear they have exceeding good natural Parts, and readily conceive our Meaning, [Aside.] I'll acquaint my Lady that you are here, Senior.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Prethee do—So, I am enter'd, but how I shall come off, I am not able to determine: If instead of a Lady, there shou'd come an old surly Dog, with half a dozen Bravoes at his back, it would give a strange turn to my Inclinations; how foolishly a Man must look upon such an Occasion; egad sup∣pose some Body should be doing me the same favour in England now with my Wife, cou'd I be angry? No faith; if a Man is born to be a Cuckold 'tis none of his Wife's fault, and therefore Senior, Don, what de call 'em, by your leave, if your Wife be handsome.

Ha! here she comes; a thousand Darts issue from her Eyes—What a Forehead's there? Her Lips exceed the redness of the Coral—'tis sure the Queen of Love—Ay, 'tis she, those dimples in her Cheeks are Cupid's bathing Tubs, and that snowy
Bosome the Plain he keeps his Revels on—Seniora [Going towards her.] the duce take me if I can speak to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: You seem surpriz'd, Senior.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Who can look on such amazing Brighness without asto∣nishment of Sense? Semele, when Jove approach'd her in all his Glory, had not more cause to be surpriz'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: You begin as if we had years to waste in Court∣ship, Senior, pray descend from your high-flown Raptures, the Gods are no Example, let us talk like Mortals.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: But are you sure, Madam, that you are Mortal?

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: I'm afraid he'll find me so, he's a charming hand∣some Fellow. [Aside.] By your Distance one wou'd imagine that you took me for a Shadow, but you may venture to approach, I am Flesh and Blood, I shan't vanish. Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Say you so Madam? Why then have at you, I was never afraid of Flesh and Blood in my Life—Ha! The Devil! a Dagger!
SP.STAGE: [Runs to catch her in his Arms, she holds up a Dagger, he starts back.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha; what, do you start at a Dagger, Se∣nior?

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Yes, in a Female Hand, those Limbs were made for softer Uses; and we Britains are not wont to see our Ladies arm'd with Steel: Loves Combats are fought with Kisses, in my Country, I know not what his Laws are here.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: The Engagements are the same, only a little dif∣ference in the Preparation; a Wound in the Reputation of an English Woman, they say, only lets in Allimony, but with us it lets out Life: And therefore, tho' we proceed with caution, a Lover ought to think us sincere, when we run such hazards to receive him.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: But to what end is the Dagger, Madam; is it to dispatch your Lover by way of keeping the Secret—faith he'll have but small stomach to Eat, that knows he must Die as soon as he has Din'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: No Senior, by this I wou'd imprint in your Mind the danger which we are both expos'd to, if we are not both discreet; Favours in Portugal must not be boasted off.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P:
Nor any where else, Madam; a Man of Honour scorns so poor a piece of Treachery; he that owns he ever had a Favour,
proclaims himself both lewd and foolish, but he that points the Woman out is a Villain, and ought to have that Dagger in his Heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Nobly said. [Throws away the Dagger.] That Sen∣tence has disarm'd and left me at your Mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Then thus I seize, and thus I will revenge the Arts you took to fright me. Ha! her Kisses would warm the Dead, I'm all Extacy. I fancy the next Room is more private Madam, and I have a secret to impart of mighty Consequence, therefore pre∣thee let's withdraw.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Oh happy English Women, that have such Men as these plenty. Oh my Heart, I find I have not power to deny him—Open that Door, Margaritta.
SP.STAGE: [Opens the Door, Marplot flops down the Chimney, the Women shriek, Charles draws his Sword, Mar-plot roars out, the Women run off.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: So, so, they understand one another,

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ah, Zounds I have broke my Leg.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Ah! Thieves, Thieves.

SP.SPEAKER: Mona Per.
SP.P: Ah! Murder, Murder.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Mar-plot! The Devil break your Neck, which way got you hither? I have a good mind to stick you, you Rascal.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: falls on his Knees.] Ah, dear Charles, is it you? Oh forgive me for Heav'ns sake, this was pure Accident, as I hope to be sav'd, the Devil take me if I dreamt of finding you.
Within.] Thieves! Murder! Murder!

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Death, they'll raise the House, and I shall be taken for a Thief, the Women will swear they know nothing of me, I war∣rant 'em. Rogue, Dog, Poultroon.
SP.STAGE: [Beats Mar-plot, and Exits into the Closet.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Nay, good Charles——Oh, oh, oh, what shall I do? Oh Lord, oh Lord, dear Charles take me out with you [Exit after Charles, and returns.] Oh, woe's me that ever I was born, he is leapt into the River; was there ever such an unfortunate Dog as I am, to be in quest of one, and tumble upon t'other? tho' if I cou'd but get safe out, and Charles scape with Life, the Accident wou'd not displease me neither, but if Charles be drown'd, I shall hang my self, that's certain.
Within.] Thieves, Thieves! Lorenzo, Pedro Sancho; where are you all?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Oh frightful! the whole House is up in Arms, which way shall I escape? Ah! methinks I feel a Spado thro' my Guts already: Egad, there is no way but up the Chimney again.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Don Perriera and his Wife; Margaritta, and other Servants arm'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Whre are these Rogues, my Dear? I'll swinge 'em. How many was there?

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: We saw ten at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Yes indeed did we—with Pistols and Spa∣does, and Heav'n knows what. Is my Lover got off clear? [Aside to Marg.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Without Dispute, for the Ladder is gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: What cou'd that Fellow be? I wish he was no Spy from my Brother Don Lopez. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Why where are they all? And which way got they in?

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: They all came down the Chimney, Senior.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Down the Chimney? here, Rascal, search the Chimney.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Take heed, Lorenza, and kill the first you light on—The Dead can discover nothing. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Here's one of 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Take him alive, I charge you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Ah! then all will out, and I'm ruin'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: How now, Sir? What are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I can't tell what I am, Sir, not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: 'Tis an Englishman, and can't belong to Don Lo∣pez. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Can't you so, Sir? Death! how came you here?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Nay, I know as little of that too, for my part; what will become of me? These Fellows have damn'd Murdering Faces. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Where are the rest of your Gang, Sirrah?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Nay, Heav'n knows; wou'd I were with them.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Zounds, Sirrah, answer without these Equivoca∣tions, or, by St. Anthony, I'll have you wrack'd to Death.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ah! the Devil take your Popish Saints; for they are always bloody-minded: I can't think of any tolerable Lye to save my Life now. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Why don't you speak, I say? Where are the other Nine? Here was Ten of you just now.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ten! As I hope for Mercy from your Hands, Sir, I saw but one; and how he came here, may I be castrated if I know. 'Tis true, he is a Friend of mine, but I won't answer for his Virtue for all that, when there is a handsome Woman in the case; for Beauty is a Temptation, you know, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Undone! this Fellow knew the other. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: How's this? a handsome Woman—I wish my Wife has not a Hand in the Plot. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: [Aside to Mar-plot.] Recal what you have said; not one Word more of the Man you saw here, as you hope to live two Hours.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ah, wretched Mar-plot, what will become of thee? [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Did you not tell me you saw ten arm'd Men come down the Chimney, Wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: For my part I was so frighted, my Dear, that I durst have sworn I saw twenty.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Ay, so did I too, Senior; for People in a Fright see double.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Pray Heav'n, some body had no Design to be double. [Aside.] Where is this Friend of your's, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What Friend, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Why him you said you saw here just now.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ah! that was all a Mistake, Sir; I did not know what I said, Sir, nor, I believe, did not know what I meant, and I'm sure I did not neither, except I meant my self, Sir. Nay, now I think on't, I did mean my self, Sir—Oh Lord, oh Lord, which way shall I come off? [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Don't stammer so, Rascal; I shall have no Mercy on you presently——Did you not say you saw a Friend of yours here?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Why if I did, Sir, I meant my self; and there needs no Logick to prove a Man's best Friend is himself, tho' I am sure I am my own worst Foe. Oh, I shall swoond away with the Fright. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: You said, you knew not how he came here nei∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: My self again, Sir; for as I hope to get safe out, I had no more Design to come into your House, than I had to eat it, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: And dare not you swear for your own Virtue nei∣ther ?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: No really, Sir, no Man knows his own Strength; and I confess ingenuously, Sir, that a pretty Woman has Power to dissolve my Resolutions of Virtue at any time.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Say you so, Sir? Why then there are things to be us'd to preserve Virtue, which I'll take care to administer I'll engage you shall attempt no Man's Wife for the future. Here, bind his Hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: 'Tis a handsome Young-Man, and no Fool. I wish I cou'd tell how to save him. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ah, dear Sir, what do you mean? I design upon a Man's Wife! Upon my Soul, Sir, I never had any such damna∣ble Design in my Days, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Sirrah, Sirrah, you wou'd not have come down my Chimney for nothing; you are a Rogue, I see by your Dis∣guise, Sirrah. Bind him, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Dar.
SP.P: Disguise! hold, hold, if the Truth must out, it must; then to deal ingenuously—

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Ah! now it comes out, I'm ruin'd past Redemption. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I am very subject to an itching in my Nature to know every body's Concerns, and being thrust out of an Officer's Lodgings of my Acquaintance, for my Impertinence (as he call'd it) I suspected he had some Intrigue on foot: So I watch'd his coming out; but finding he shut himself up, I imagin'd he had got his Mistress with him. So, Sir, I found means to get in again; but not meeting with him, I fancy'd he had some private way up the Chimney. So, Sir, my confounded Curio∣sity, with a Pox to't, must needs try to smell him out—So, Sir, I turn'd my Coat here to save it clean, and up I scrambl'd; but when I came without-side, I saw no body there then: Sir, some∣thing whisper'd me in my Ear, that he might be gone down the next Chimney: So, Sir, that devilish Desire of mine brought me down hither, as you see, Sir; and this is the Truth, and no∣thing but the Truth, as I hope for your Pardon, Sir—Ah, poor Mar-plot, if this brings thee not off, thou art undone for ever. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P:
A well compact Lye. I'll Officer you, with the Devil to you. I suppose your Country-men think they have a License for Cuckoldom. Do you hear? search the whole House; for this Rogue in Red may lurk in some Corner or other, and
watch his Opportunity to press my Wife to the Service, and think to raise Recruits out of my Family: And for you, sweet Senior Sweep-Chimney, the Corrigadore shall let you into the Secrets of our Laws in Portugal.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: The Devil take all Secrets for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Lorenzo, go let him know his Presence is requir'd. Come, Sir, I shall put you into a safer Place till he comes, where there is no Chimney to get out at. Margaritta, take care of my Wife—Hold, now I think on't, I'll ease you of that Trouble, and do it my self. Go, get in there.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: What Fault have I committed, my Dear, to be imur'd? If I had not cry'd out, you had not taken this Villain.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I wish you had been dumb, with all my Blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: When he is gone, and the House found to be clear, you shall have your Liberty again; therefore no Dispute, but in, I say.
Now bring him along into the next Chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: O you malignant Stars—Oh, take pity upon me, and let me go, or I shall die with Vexation, and you'll be accessary to my Murder, and that will trouble your Conscience.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Conscience! you Heretick Dog; do you talk of Conscience? Drag him along.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Heretick Dog! a good Hint; ad, I'll pretend to turn Papist. Oh, hear me one Moment, Sir; I do confess I am a Heretick, and my Conscience tells me very unfit to die. Ah, dear Sir, be so charitable to afford me a little Instruction, and recommend me to some Saint that may take care of me in the other World.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Oh, Anthony! thou hast touch'd his Heart, and put me upon a meritorious Action—I must have regard to his poor Soul—Well, young Man, since I find thou art become the Care of Heav'n, I think thee worthy my Regard. I'll send for a Priest that shall instruct thee in the Mysteries of our Religion. Come, come along.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ah, for some Instructions how to get out; here's a little time gain'd however.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P:
Well, by St. Anthony, I am much concern'd for him, methinks I feel a more than ordinary motion about my Heart. Ha! My pulses beat quicker than they used to do; oh dear, how my Breasts heave; I am much disorder'd, but I believe my Di∣stemper
wou'd not prove dangerous, were he my Physician; well, if I thought he would be grateful I'd release him. I have a Key will open that Door; besides, he knows my Lady's Gallant, and perhaps they may force him to discover who he is, and where he lodges; and if he falls into Don Lopez's Hands, fare him well, and farewel my Fees too; now if I convey him out, I may prevent future Mischief, and may be get a Love of my own, at least I cannot fail of Rewards from all sides, I'll do't I'm re∣solv'd.
Well Senior Englise, what think you of finding out secrets again?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: For my part I shall hate every thing that is but spell'd with any one Letter that belongs to it: Have you no Bowels of Mercy for one neither? Ah, Seniora, for honest Charles's sake let me go, you see I brought you off, then prethee take some pity on me

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Fie Senior, a Lady may compassionate your Person for your own sake, to do you Justice, you are a clever young Man, and may make your Fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I wish I cou'd make my Escape,

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Suppose a Lady shou'd take a liking to you, cou'd you be kind?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Kind? ods Heart, is it possible for a Man to think of kindness when the Knife's at his Throat—What the Devil does this old Hag mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: But set the case a Woman shou'd procure the liberty of your Person, what Charms must she be Mistress off to cap∣tivate your Heart?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Charms! Egad if she had never a Nose, I should think my self bound in Honour to be grateful.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Tho' she was not altogether so young.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Nay, tho' she were as old again as thou art, I wou'd love her monstrously. I fancy 'tis her self she means; egad I begin to conceive hopes of Liberty. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Indeed! And do you really think you cou'd love me, Senior?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Do you really think you can let me out?

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: It lies in my Power.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Why then t'other shall lye in my Will: And to prove my Love, there's Gold for thee, old Girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg
SP.P:
This is as it should be now, nothing like Earnest to bind
Bargain—Well Senior, upon condition you'll meet me whenever I shall give you Notice, I'll take pity on you, and let you Escape.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: My Angel, my Life, my Soul; od I'm wondrous full of Raptures of a sudden.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Hark, I hear some Body coming, follow me quickly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: With all my Spirit.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Don Perriera, and Don Lopez.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P: Stupidity! Give a Villain fair play for his Life, that wou'd rob you of your Honour! What business cou'd this Fel∣low have in your House? And by so Clandestine a way as the Chimney? Where is he? give him to my Revenge.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Nor for the World; you wou'd not kill him now, when he is willing to be Converted: Just when his Eyes are opening? That wou'd be to destroy his Soul with his Body.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P: His Soul? I'd rather give a hundred Moydres to have it pray'd out of Purgatory, then lose my Revenge. Open the Door I say, or I will force it open.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: I say you shall not see him till the Corrigadore comes, I'll deliver him into the Hands of Justice; I will not have a Man murder'd without a just Cause; touch the Door if you dare, I'd have you to know I am Master of my own Lodgings.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P: And I'd have you to know, Sir, that I'll batter your Lodgings about your Ears, before I'll suffer in my Honour: Where is this salacious Woman, this adulterous Sister, this Con∣taminated fair One, this Viper of our Family?

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Safe enough out of your reach I know she's inno∣cent of this, and therefore will preserve her. Pray mittigate your Passion, Senior, and you shall have all the satisfaction in this matter you can desire from a Brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P: Brother! Dam the Alliance, I scorn the Title.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Right, just as my Wife said—he does hate me heartily— [Enter Servant.] How now, is the Corrigadore come?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: Yes Sir, he's without.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Bring him in.

I charge you, Senior Don Garcia Pedro Compostello, to keep the Peace, and protect the Prisoner which I shall deliver into your Hands from the fury of Senior Don Lopez, whose fiery
Temper hurries him on to execute, before he knows the Na∣ture of the Offence.

SP.SPEAKER: Cor.
SP.P: Sure you mistake, Senior; Rashness has no Connexion with true Courage; and I look upon Don Lopez to be a Person of a singular good Conduct.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P: Rot your fawning Praise—Do Justice, demand your Prisoner, let me see the English Dog.

SP.SPEAKER: Cor.
SP.P: Nay Senior, if you are in earnest, I am oblig'd by my Offices to keep the Peace; disarm him.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P: A Curse of your Authority.

SP.SPEAKER: Cor.
SP.P: Now Don Perriera, bring out the Offender.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: That I will. Here open that Door, and bring him hither.
SP.STAGE: [Gives a Key to a Servant; who Exits, and returns.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: Here is no Body within, Sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: How! no Body within? Ah, thou art a blind Booby.
SP.STAGE: [Goes in, and returns hastily, crossing himself.
SP.P: Mercy upon me! The Rogue was in the right, there is no Body there, 'twas certainly the Devil, and he's gone through the Key∣hole; for no Humane Creature cou'd get out; bless me, how I tremble!

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P: The Devil! I wish I had met with that Devil, I'd have try'd to have made him Mortal for the good of Mankind.

SP.SPEAKER: Cor.
SP.P: Pray let's see this Room from whence he escap'd, per∣haps he may be hid somewhere.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Oh, it is to no purpose, there is nothing to be seen.

HEAD.STAGE: [The Scene draws, and discovers them searching about.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P: Hark ye Don Perriera, if your Wife be not va∣nish'd too, prethee ask her what Species he was compos'd of, I warrant, she can tell you, he had no sulphureous Scent about him.

SP.SPEAKER: Cor.
SP.P: 'Tis very odd; was the Door lock'd are you sure?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: Yes Senior, I'm sure I unlock'd it.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: I lock'd it my self, and have had the Key in my Pocket ever since.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P: But all your Locks are not secur'd, by carrying the Key about you. I doubt Senior, I hope I may put on my Spado again.

SP.SPEAKER: Cor.
SP.P: Pray be certain of your Criminals, Senior, the next time you send for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: S'death! am I flouted—I have lost all Patience, I'd give my whole Estate to know which way this Dog escap'd, if he were Flesh and Blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P: Ask your Wife that,—Confusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: My Wife! If I shou'd find my Wife guilty, I'd practice such unheard of Cruelties on her, as shou'd out-do our Inquisition.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P: Pshaw! All Talk, all Talk; you shou'd have crush'd when in your Power, but then the Law must right you; you had a meritorious Work to do, there was so much care taken on his Soul, that you left the Body unguarded, and it has made bold to slip thro' your Fingers: Confound your Ignorance.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Amen I say, with all my Heart, and send me more Sense—I own my good Nature has abus'd me, but here I throw it off; and now, Senior, I am apt for any Impression, your Will shall be my Law; say what's to be done?

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P: Why, if you will take my Advice, cause diligent search to be made thro' all the Family, there is certainly a false Key to that Door, and those you find it upon dispatch, but rack 'em first to bring the Secret out.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: It shall be done. What more?

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P: If you find it not, put on the same Humour you us'd to wear, seem not to suspect my Sister, but pretend some Business at St. Ubes for two or three Days; take your leave, return privately, and conceal your self in some convenient Place: I warrant you'll make sufficient Discovery.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: All this I'll observe to a tittle, and if I do find her false, by St. Anthony she dies.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P: In the mean time I'll not be Idle, my Revenge shall pursue these English Dogs so close, that I'll find out this Villain, or write Villain on the Heart of all his Country-Men.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: A Curse of the Cause that brought these Whore-masters to Portugal. What a numerous Progeny will they leave behind them; the next Generation will be all Mungrils—But I'll endeavour to prevent the Increase in my Family.

L.HI: Woman, thy Constancy I go to try:
Blest if thou'rt true—but if you're false you die.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: HA, ha, ha; certainly this Fellow is the most mischie∣vous Rogue that ever liv'd; which way got he down the Chimney?

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Nay that's past my finding out, as also what's become of him: I cou'd have cut his Throat with all my Soul just then, and yet I can't help being concern'd for him now, I fear he is kill'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: I shou'd be sorry for that, tho' in my Conscience he de∣serves it, this busie humour of his is as natural to him as his Food; he follow'd me home this Morning, I was forc'd to use him very roughly to get rid of him, for you must know, I have a trap Door in my Chimney, thro' which I descend into a back Street, where I am conducted by an old Negro to an Angel of a Woman; I had her Summons, and the hour of Assignation was come when he en∣ter'd my Chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: A very unseasonable Visit, faith Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Ay, was it not? but I quickly dispatch'd him, tho' how he stumbl'd upon you afterwards, and in so odd a manner, is a miracle.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: If he lives we shall know when next we meet; I never catch'd him in a lye, which is the best Qualification he has: But Colonel, did not you promise to introduce me to your French Mistress? What, this Lady incog. has not beat her out by the by, has she Colonel?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: No, no, she maintains her Ground too well, there's more danger of my raising the Siege, than her beating the Chamade; she has so many retreats of Pride, Vanity, and Affectation, that without some lucky Accident toss a Granade into the Magazine of her Inclination, there'll be no hopes of the Town.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Storm then, Colonel, storm.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: I rather chuse to block her up and starve her out, suffer no Admirer to enter; and if once a Woman of her temper want the Provision of Vanity, she surrenders of course.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: An admirable Stratagem, but prithee let me see her before you put it in practice.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: It shall be now, if you please, Charles.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: With all my Heart: Is it far?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: At that House, yonder.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Lead the way then.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Lead the way—where the Devil are they going? now can't I help having a violent desire to follow them, tho' I scap'd so narrowly in my last Project: Yonder they go, ha! they are enter'd already, that is no publick House I'm sure: Egad, may be it is some private Bourdell, or what business can both of 'em have at one House? Well, Charles, tho' you was so barbarous to desert me in my Afflictions, I won't serve you so, I'll not stir from this place 'till I see you safe out—Od, upon second thoughts I'll knock at the Door, and ask for him, perhaps three may be as welcome as two.
SP.STAGE: [As he is going to knock, enter Isabinda in Boys Cloaths.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Ha! Mar-plot here, this is lucky. [Aside.] Mr. Mar∣plot, fortunately met.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: That's more than I can tell yet, for I don't know you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Nor wou'd I have you, [Aside.] But you know those that do; can you tell me where Mr. Charles Gripe is to be found?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ha! my Mind misgives me plaguily that this is an En∣voy from the old Man's Wife, pray Heav'n he has never a Sum∣mons from my old Matron too; for tho' I comply'd with all she ask'd to purchase my Liberty, I am sure I shall have no Stomach to perform Articles. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Don't you hear me, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Yes, yes, Sir, I hear you—What the duce shall I say to him, he must not know that Charles is gone into yon House; for Women here, they say, are cursed Jealous, and that may be a means to have his Throat cut. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Why don't you answer? where does he Lodge?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Where does he Lodge?—this must be some new In∣treague, for doubtless t'other knows his Lodgings: Look ye, Sir, one good turn deserves another; let me know what business you have with him, and accordingly as I like it, your Question shall be answered.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Mar-plot still, I find he's no changling. [Aside] Why then, Sir, if you must know, I have a Letter for him from a La∣dy who is desperately in love with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: So, here's another Intreague popt into my Mouth. In Love with him? prithee dear Youth who is she? where does she live? What's her Name? Is she Maid, Wife, or Widow? Young, or Old? Black, Brown, or Fair? Short, or Tall? Fat, or Lean? this Country, or a Foreigner? quick, quick, quick my dear lit∣tle Rogue, let me into the secret, and I'll carry thee to his Lodg∣ings immediately—Egad this Discovery will make my peace with Charles compleatly.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: I can only answer him these questions, Sir, I am no Blab, you must excuse me if I'm silent.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: So must you me, Sir, I'm no Blab neither, Sir, if you go to that, I'd have you to believe I can keep my Friend's secrets when intrusted; I don't know his Lodgings, find them out as you can.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: You are very short, Sir; I have nothing to say against your secrecy, but it wou'd be Impudence in me to run the hazard, besides forestalling your Friend's Generosity, he ought to have the disposal of his own secrets.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ay, if it comes into his Hands once 'twill cost me more pains to find out? than 'tis worth.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Pains to find out? I hope you never endeavour to find out what other People wou'd conceal.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: No? yes to chuse; why the duce shou'd any Man know more than my self? We came into the World alike, and I can see no occasion for his superior knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: I admire you are not for levelling Estates too; how can you bear any Man to be richer than your self?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Oh with ease, my Wealth lies in my Mind, I had rather fathom the depth of a Man's Thoughts, than his Pockets; yet to show you I can suppress my Curiosity, let me read the Letter, and I'll excuse the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: It is as much as my Life's worth to open the Letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Pox take his Life—tell me what's in't then, or may I be carbonaded if you know his Lodgings. I'd give a Finger to have this Intreague rightly. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P:
I must not let this Fellow know me, if I intend to con∣ceal my being in Lisbon; I'll humour him a little, and try what
discovery I can make. [Aside.] Well, Sir, if you'll promise to be secret, I'll let you into this Affair.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Secret as a Priest, Child—Egad I shall have it, pray Heav'n Charles does not come out before he has done, if he shou'd I should be undone. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Why then the Lady I belong to, is a rich Merchant's Daughter, near the Convent of Santo Vincente, her Name is Dona Cephisa, she saw your Friend at Church, is extremely charm'd with him, and resolves to marry him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Marry him! ha, ha, ha, ha, poor Lady! why now to return secret for your secret, he's Married already, but perhaps he may prick her down amongst the rest of his Mistresses: You understand me?

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Too well—the rest of his Mistresses? has he such store then?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: As many as he can well manage, I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Oh my Heart, the danger of intreaguing in this place alarms my fears, and shocks my very Soul.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What I have said makes you thoughtful, I perceive; will no Body do but Charles? What think you of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Why really, Sir, were I a Woman, I shou'd prefer you before him, but I can't answer for my Lady; if you please I'll mention you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Your most humble Servant, Sir,—Egad there may be new pleasure in having an Intreague of ones own, for ought I know, for I never had one in my Life. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: But, Sir, there is one Article in our Agreement which you have not perform'd,

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Where your Friend lodges?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Why he lodges at yon green Windows, where if you have any Service from your Lady for your humble Servant, you'll find me there also.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Sir I kiss your Hand, I'll do my best to serve you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P:
Sir, I kiss yours—I'm glad he's gone before Charles came out; this is a Nonsensical Secret, tho' methinks I had rather know what the Colonel and he is doing in yon House—Shall I knock at the Door or not? If I shou'd, ten to one but I do Mis∣chief—and shall be beaten again: To prevent which I'll wait
within sight for their coming out, so when they are pass'd by, I may with more Security make my Enquiry.

HEAD.STAGE: SCENE Changes to Mademoisel Joneton's Lodgings.

DIV2.STAGE: She drest Fantastically modish, with her Sister Marton, and two other Ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Susan, bring me the Glass.

SP.SPEAKER: Susan.
SP.P: Yes, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Don't I look wretchedly to Day, Sister?

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: Your looks are the same to Day they always are, I see no Difference.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: How do you mean that, Sister? That I always look cursedly, or how?

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: She looks too well for my Ease, since she's belov'd by Colonel Ravelin. [Aside.] I'm sure your Vanity and Affectation does not put that Construction upon my Words, Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Affectation! Ladies, pray what am I affected in? Nay, take the Glass away again.
My Sister Marton says, I'm affected, so I will not look in't, to oblige her: Am I not very complisant, Ladies?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Lad.
SP.P: Mademoisel Joneton is always so, I think you have the most agreeable manner of speaking—

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: Fye Madam, how can you do your Reason so much Violence, to commend the most ridiculous Humour that ever Woman took up, it must needs be agreeable to hear Words spun out to half an Hours length.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Lad.
SP.P: Well, I must own I like it in her extremely, I think there is a particular Grace in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: Yes, it is something particular truly, sometimes to talk as fast as School-Boys read, and other some so slow, that we for∣get the Sense of the Argument before she has done speaking.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: One wou'd really think my Sister of Spanish Production, she is so formal—I see no reason why one may not alter and change the Form and Manner of speaking, according to the Company one keeps, as well as the Mode and Fashion of one Clothes—Now when I converse with my own Sex, I love to indulge my self, and let my Words fall from me with Indolence and Ease, because their Conversation is insipid, and we only prattle away time.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: Insipid! Ha, ha, ha, pray what relish have the Mens beyond ours?

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Oh, that Question is Preposterous—But you have no Taste Sister, you detest Mankind.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: Ay, but the Colonel has found the way to Convert that Notion. [Aside.] I confess, Sister, I never cou'd see any thing in those lordly Creatures of force enough to make me submit blind∣ly to their tyrannick Sway.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: But there's a vast Pleasure in making them submit to ours, to make so fine a Gentleman as Colonel Ravelin obey my Nod, sigh, weep and kneel at ones Frown, then give him Rap∣tures with a Smile. The Colonel! Oh! the most engaging Man alive—When he comes next you shall see him, Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: Not for the Spanish Mines—I am too well acquainted with the Colonel, which she must not know. [Aside.] Excuse me Sister, I shou'd only spoil your Conversation.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Lad.
SP.P: Does Madamoisel Marton hold her Resolution of a Monestery yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: have not yet laid aside all Thoughts on't, Madam—tho' 'tis in the Colonel's Power to make me do it, I fear. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Well, follow your own way, get up to a Six a Clock Mass, then stitch till Dinner, tattle away your Hours with two or three silly Women, till Vespers; then work again till Bed∣time; and have no Pleasure beyond a Dream.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: Oh wou'd I cou'd retrieve that tranquil State, she talks of what I was. [Aside.] Every one to their Inclinations, Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Lad.
SP.P: But pray inform me, Madamoisel Joneton, for I am very Ambitious of coping you, where lies the Magick in Men to alter your manner of speaking?

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Desire to please sets all the Senses in a Ferment, and Inclination presses so hard upon the Faculty of Speech, that our Words hurry out with Precipation, Vanity musters the Force of our Charms, and Pride leads us on the attack of our Wishes, and a janty Variety of Airs compleat the Conquest.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Here's Collonel Ravelin and another Gentleman to wait on you, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Bring 'em up; une outer Galant.
SP.STAGE: [Rising in a hurry, and running to the Glass.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: Ha! the Collonel, oh my Heart: I must be gone, I wou'd not have him know me for the World—Well, Sister, I'll leave you to your desirable Company.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Adieu, ma Soer—ah Maria Mater! how I look to day, je suis lead comme le diable.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: We'll wait on you another time, Mademoisel.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: When you please, my dear Ladies.
Ah Monsieur le Colonel, je suis ravi de vous voir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Ah Madmoisel Joneton, je meur tout le moment que je ete absant de vous.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Ah Cela galant, ha, ha, ha, I have a most comical Story to tell you, ha, ha, ha; such an Amour, ha, ha, such a Letter, ha, ha, such a Conquest; le pleaser une Chatulez, ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Oh pleasant Ravishment, ha, ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: What is it that is so Ravishing, Colonel, in your Opini∣on? [Very gravely.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Well Question'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Your Letter, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Then have you seen it, ma chear Colonel?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Not I, Madam, I depend upon your superior Judgment for the Merit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Most politely said: You are certainly the best bred Man in Europe, Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: I am sure this is the worst proof of his being so I ever knew him give. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: You are certainly the most polite diverting charming Wo∣man that ever told a Story; but pray proceed, Madam; the Let∣ter, ha, ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Oh ridiculous! a Letter from a High Dutch Servant; you shall hear it Colonel.
Ha, ha, ha, methinks it has a rumbling sound.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: He makes Love like a Cannon, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: A mon Dieu! What makes me so merry? I am sure I have cause enough to the contrary; my poor Paroquet is dead, Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Dead!

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Dead, it died upon my Hand, it talk'd and buss'd me to the last moment; oh my Heart is broke, oh, oh, oh, oh,

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: So she's resolv'd to play over all her tricks I see. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Oh I can't contain my self when I think on't, oh, oh.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Oh unlucky Accident; give her Air.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: In my Opinion she has already too much of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Mrs. Susan, loose her Lace; within there, bring some cold Water.
She revives; for Heav'ns sake how do you do, Madam? Come, I'll procure you another Paroquet.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Oh not so divertisant, it had a thousand pretty Actions; one day as Monsieur le Markee de belle Jambe was entertaining me with a Recital of his Amours—ha, ha, ha, I have a pleasant Tale to tell you of him too, ha, ha, ha, he's marriy'd, ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Upon the titter again, deliver me from such a medley I say. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: To a thirty thousand Pound Fortune, ha, ha, but the Estate lies in terra incognita, I have recommended Imagination for his Steward, and Philosophy for his Equipage, ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: The Marquiss let into the secret, ha, ha, pray who is the Lady that has done him the favour?

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Oh my Stars what ails me? ah Maria Mater, the Room goes round.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: A Chair there, Mrs. Susan; repose your self a little, Madam, 'tis only Vapours and will off again; these affectations in another I shou'd hate, but here I'm fated to the folly.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Most fantastical: the duce take me if I can bring my self to the Complacence of asking her how she does. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: How do you, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Oh much better, Colonel, 'tis impossible any Malady can stay long in your Company; I admire your Friend can be so melancholy with a Companion so diverting.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: I confess the Colonel is of a singular good humour, Ma∣dam, for an Englishman; we, generally speaking, are dull heavy thinking Animals, not mov'd by the losing of a Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Most unpolite, such a Lover as this would make me as splenetick as fourscore.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Alas, Madam, he's married.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P:
Married! nay then I forgive him;—yet upon second thoughts, I won't neither, for he ought to have left his dogged
Humours at home, and not stamp Wife in the Forehead of every Woman he meets.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: He's mad that wou'd stamp any thing upon thee, I'm sure. [Aside.] Since I offend you, Madam, I humbly take my leave. [Going.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: I beg you wou'd excuse the bluntness of my Friend, Ma∣dam, he's a very honest Fellow. Oh that I cou'd look upon her with his indifference. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Oh fie Colonel, why that request? Your Friend is a fine Gentleman—Mais je ne scay pas en qui—Nay, you shan't go, Monsieur; you being a married Man, must understand every thing that belongs to our Sex.
SP.STAGE: [Runs and pulls him back by the Coat.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Heav'n deliver me from the Study. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha; poor Charles, how he frets. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Here! give me your Opinion, how do you like these Cloaths?

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: As I like every thing else that belongs to them, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: A very odd Expression that—but don't you think our Airs plus Engageant, than the Ladies in England, Monsieur? How did your Lady dress, to catch your Heart?

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: I never minded the Airs of her Person, Madam, she had other Charms for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: This Fellow will give me the Hip confoundedly, if he goes on thus—What! she sings; I fancy you love singing, Mon∣sieur—come I'll oblige you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: She resolves to teaze him. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Well, Monsieur, Comment agrez vous cela?

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: The Words are very pretty, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: And your manner of singing extremely engaging.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: That's not your Friend's Opinion, Colonel: He has cer∣tainly no Soul. If all his Sex were such mortifying Animals, what a number of fasting Days shou'd we have in the Kalender; we shou'd have no need of Indulgences, Pardons, and Penance; we shou'd live Saints, and dye without the fear of Purgato∣ry. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Colonel, you'll excuse me if I leave you, for faith she has tired my Patience. [Aside to Rav.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: No, prithee tarry a little longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: What are you two whispering about? You shan't go 'till you have drank some Tea; Susan, get Water for Tea, and set the Table ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Susan.
SP.P: 'Tis ready in the next Room, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: My Friend is a lover of Tea, and was just enquiring of me where I thought the best was to be got.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: The Devil take his Excuse, now there is no getting off. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: That I am Mistress of any thing worth his Admiration, is no small pleasure to me; I dare be vain to say, I can recommend him to the best in Portugal. Along Messieurs. Fa, la, la, lera lal.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: They stay a cursed while, Egad I'll e'en ask for Charles; the Story this young Fellow brought of a Letter will be a rare excuse. [Going up to the Door.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter a Bravo with a Letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Bravo.
SP.P: What Countryman are you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Countryman, Sir? why I am an Englishman, Sir, I'm not asham'd of my Country.

SP.SPEAKER: Bravo.
SP.P: I have a Letter for an Englishman, but those that sent it don't know his Name.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: From a Lady I warrant? Egad here's another Intreague of some Bodies pop'd in my way now; I've a good mind to own the Letter, open it and see what's in't; but if it shou'd come from the old Woman—Pray, Sir, does it come from Youth or Age?

SP.SPEAKER: Bravo.
SP.P: From Youth and Fire, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Because I expect a Summons from a very beautiful young Lady my self.

SP.SPEAKER: Bravo.
SP.P: Your Description is just, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Say you so, Sir, why then I believe it is for your humble Servant, Sir. Discoveries come thick to day.
I am a lucky Dog, Faith.

SP.SPEAKER: Bravo.
SP.P: Not unlikely; there it is, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P:
Ah Colonel, ah Charles, what wou'd you give to be in
my place now? But hang it, I'm good-natur'd, she shall fall to one of your shares, for I wou'd not give a Half-penny for the finest Wo∣man in Lisbon, for my own sake. [Opens and reads.] What's here? The Reader is a Villain, and deserves to have his Throat cut. Surprising! upon my Soul, Sir, this Letter does not belong to me. I am a lucky Dog now indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P: Upon my Soul, Sir, you lie. Draw Sirrah, or I'll rip your Guts up.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Draw, Sir? for what, Sir? Oh bloody-minded Wretch, what will come of me? [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P: For opening the Letter, Villain.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ah pox of my Curiosity—The Devil take the Letter, 'twas none of my seeking, the Fellow said it was for an English∣man, an, an, an I did not know but it might have been for me as well as another; I ask your Pardon with all my Heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P: Rot your Compliment; if it had come from my Sister it had been for you, Sir; therefore Draw, or by St. Anthony—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Sister! as I hope to be sav'd, Sir, I know never a Man's Sister in the Universe.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P: Cowardly Dog, [beats him.] dare to lie with a Man's Wife, and not dare to fight for her?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Mercy upon me, I lie with a Man's Wife? oh, Sir, you are the most mistaken in me that ever you was in your days, Sir; Upon my Faith, I never knew what Woman was, nay, Sir, I never car'd for a Woman, that's more—But indeed here is two or three Gentlemen of my Acquaintance very much given that way.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P: Is there so, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Oh exceedingly—now I won't swear it is not one of them. I wish I were fairly rid of him. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P: Your Safety depends upon your Information, let me know where to find them, and you shall live.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Colonel Ravelin and Charles behind them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Thank you heartily, Sir,—What a cursed Premenary I have brought my self into now, for Egad I'll not tell where Charles lives, if I dye for't—I'll, I'll, I'll tell him a wrong Place, I'm resolv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P: Come, where do they lodge? What are you studying for, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I, I, I, I, can't think of the name of the Street for my Blood—it is, it is—what de ye call the Street when you turn the Corner of your right Hand, and then turn again of your left, and then again of the right, and so back by the left, an, an, an, so, an, an a cross the what de call 'em, an, an.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P: No equivocating, Sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: I thought it was Mar-plot's Voice.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Since he lives, well preserve him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ah, good Sir, I, I, I, I, I,—Ah Charles, dear Charles.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Guard your Life, Sir, or cease to insult this Gentleman.
SP.STAGE: [They beat off Don Lopez and the Bravo.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Victoria! Victoria! Faith Gentlemen you came in the lucky Minute, or I had been a dead Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Nay, in my Conscience I believe thou'lt never die in thy Bed. Which of your inquisitive Actions brought this upon you?

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
