SP.P: Was this your Chimney Adventure, or another?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: No, faith this was another, about a damn'd Letter, and Cuckolding some Body, and debauching that Spaniard's Sister, and the Devil knows what; I wish one of you two is not at the bottom of this.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Ha, ha! come Charles, we'll to your Lodgings, where he shall give us the whole Relation of his Adventures.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: With all Sincerity—and I have something else to tell you, Charles; there's a Lady in Love with you, and has sent you a Letter, but mum, you shall promise to let me into the Secret, or you shall know no more on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: How brisk the Rogue is again already? I thought you might have had enough of Secrets.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: Oh, the Mind you know is never satisfy'd.
Were all the Joys that Nature could bestow
Within my Power to taste, I'd rather know
What every Man endeavours still to hide;
And having that, wou'd care for nought beside.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Charles, Colonel Ravelin and Mar-plot.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: A Very pretty Account, ha, ha, ha, what do you ex∣pect will be the end of your Curiosity, Mar-plot?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: No good in this Country I fear, yet for my Blood I can't help it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: What, can't you help dogging People, and opening Let∣ters of no Concern to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: O' my Soul, I have made Resolutions upon Resolutions to the contrary, but to no purpose; there is a tickling desire runs thro' my Veins, which is always craving as my Stomach—and makes these Discoveries as necessary as my Food. Tho' faith I never mean any harm—Why this Letter now, who the Devil dream'd of a consumed Challenge?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: You shou'd always dream of the worst, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: That's not my Maxim, Colonel; methinks ill luck comes fast enough. Look ye Gentlemen, 'tis as much your fault as mine, if you wou'd take me with you, or tell me the bottom of things, I shou'd trouble my Head no farther; but here you leave me in the Dark, and nothing to do, but entertain my Fears, which are strong for my Friends, and most of the Mischiefs I do, proceeds from my Concern for their Safety; and here I get thump'd and beaten for my good Intentions, and that's all, on every side.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: And all you deserve; ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: There's a Gentleman below inquires for you, Sir; he has Business with you from England, he says, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: From England! who the Devil can this be now? [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Bring him up.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: I have a Letter and Packet for Mr. Charles Gripe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: I am the Person, Sir. Robin, reach a Chair; pray be pleas'd to sit, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: From England! Ha, ha, Sir, your humble Servant; why this is the very Gentleman I told you of, Charles—So, so, well, well, and how does Donna Cephisa? What, she will have him then, and no Body else? ha? What does she say to you, Charles? Ha? How does she write, Ha? Nay, egad you shall let me into this Business, Mun—for I have been chief Promoter of it I am sure, therefore no shuffling, Charles—

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: No, no, I scorn it, Mar-plot; there read, read.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Why that's civil now—Let me see how these Spanish Dames express themselves—My dearest Life—Humph—As frank and fond, as if it came from an Inhabitant of Covent-Garden, egad—I hope this will find you safely arriv'd in Lisbon—Ha, Lis∣bon—Why what the Devil does she mean? Lets see what's at bottom: From your ever loving Wife, Isabinda Gripe. A murrain Gripe you—Pish, Pox, I wonder'd you was so ready to show it me indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Ha, ha, what does not the Secret please you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Please a Fiddle-stick; why what did this young Dog mean? Egad I wish Charles wou'd beat him for the Disappoint∣ment. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: to Isab.] Pardon my Memory, Sir, I have seen your Face somewhere, but cannot recollect where.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Heav'n continue his Ignorance. [Aside.] Very likely, Sir, I have liv'd most of my time in this Place.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ay; why how in the Name of Wonder did he come by this Letter then? [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: A Factor to my Uncle, Sir Francis Tradewell, from whom I receiv'd that Pacquet, with Orders to deliver it to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Oh, so it came. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: I know Sir Francis very well, and for his sake, Sir, shou'd be prowd of being better acquainted with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Sir, you Honour me—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Pies of his Acquaintance, I say. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: I hope your Lady's well, Charles.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P:
At your Service, Colonel—She has sent the Papers I told you I forgot; now I shall dispatch my Business very quickly, she songs to see me, she says—'tis a Poor good-natur'd Tit, and I lov'd her heartily till I married her; but whether her Overfond∣ness, or the easy Access every Man has to his Wife, takes off the edge
of my Appetite, but methinks I see her not with half that desire I us'd to do, when I scal'd her Window for a Kiss, the Memory of it still is Pleasant.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ay! my Shoulders remember that time too.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Ungenerous Declaration, 'tis very unjust in my Opinion to slight the thing that loves you, I'm sure 'tis what I cou'd not do.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I fancy you never try'd the Matrimonial strength of In∣clination yet, Sir, therefore can be no Judge: Nature abhors Con∣straint.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Ay ay, Inconstancy is a fault in Nature, and who can help it?

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Right, Colonel! and when you marry Mademoisel Flut∣ter yonder, you'll have a Proof of what I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Mademoisel Flutter, who's she? I never heard of her be∣fore. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Let her look to that—I thought Charles's Wife had been a Favorite of yours, Mr. Mar-plot, but I don't hear you make the least Inquiry after her Health.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Look ye, Colonel, I hate to be baulk'd, for that puts every thing out of ones Head—Hark ye, what did you mean by telling me such a confounded Story upon the Terriera de Passe, of a rich Merchant's Daughter Dona Cephisa, and I can't tell who? What, was it all but a sham then?

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Why really, Sir, you was so inquisitive, that I had no o∣ther way to dismiss you, and it is not my Custom to let one Man into the Affairs of another.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Poor Mar-plot, thou art baulk'd every way; ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Well, there was never good times since this shuffling and lying came in Fashion.
SP.STAGE: [A Letter ty'd to a Stone, is toss'd in at the Window, Charles takes it up and Reads to himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ha day! Where the Devil came that from?

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: seeming to look out.] I fancy it came from that Fellow which looks up yonder, there is no Body else near—Ha, my Eyes deceive me, or he belongs to some Body in the House where I lodge—I'll home, and make the best Observation I can in this matter. Ah, poor Charles, these Courses are more dangerous than thou art aware of; I'll not discover my self yet, perhaps I may satisfie my Curiosity better as I am. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: An Assignation, Charles; send thee better Fortune than last time.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: 'Tis from the same Woman, Colonel—No, no, 'tis only some roguish Boy, tossing Stones about in Pieces of his Copy-Book.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Humph, but that sham won't take tho'. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Oh well dissembel'd—Sir, I'm your humble Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Sir, I hope I shall have the Honour to see you here again.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Sir, the Honour will be mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: The Trap-door is unbolted, Colonel. [Half aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What's that of a Trap-door now? Ods heart here's two confounded Intreagues on Foot, and I'm out at both, and they'll be hang'd before they'll let me into one of them. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: I'll be there immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Where, Colonel? I wish I cou'd spilt my self in half now, that I might follow them both.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Again at your Impertinence? Ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: He can't help it for his Soul—Tho' we take different Posts, Colonel, I fancy 'tis one and the same Action, Prosperity to yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: The same to thine. Mr. Mar-plot, Adieu.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What shall I do between both? Pox on't, 'tis very un∣lucky—Then you won't let me into the Secret, Colonel?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Positively no.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Nay, nay, nay, Charles, you won't both leave me, will you?

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Indeed, Mar-plot, I have extraordinary Business.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Do but tell me what it is, nay, tell me but something relating to't, and I am satisfy'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Why then to be ingenious, the Letter which was toss'd in is a Challenge, and I am going to seek for a Second; now if you cou'd Fight, you'd save me the Labour.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ah, the Devil take it, that I never learn'd to Fence—Why did you not engage the Colonel?

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Because I saw he had Affairs of his own to pursue.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What wou'd I give for Courage now—Pies on't, what is it that makes Men so stout? Egad I'm ready to weep to think I can't serve my Friend, I have the Theory of fighting, methinks—I only want the practick Part.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: So, I have found the way to drop him at last—Well, I hope you are satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Satisfied? no faith, Charles, I am not satisfied; ods Life, I'll tell you what I can do, I'll Charge my brace of Pocket Pi∣stols, and shoot him—if you will.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Oh fye, there's a dishonourable Action indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: The Devil take Honour; when Life's concern'd, what will a Man get by't?

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: I have not time at present to clear that Question, fare∣well.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Farewel! Egad 'twou'd be faring very ill tho' if he shou'd be kill'd. I wish I knew where to find Colonel Ravelin—Oh Lord, oh Lord; I never thought to ask Charles where this Duel was to be fought, and then whither cou'd I send him? Well thought on, yonder he goes, I'll follow till I fix him, and then I'll soon call Company enough to part them—Egad I love my Friend, as I love my Life.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Charles with a Rope-ladder, Mar-plot at a distance.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Let me see, she has chang'd her Appartment, she has sent me Word—Her Window now is over the Door, this must be it.
SP.STAGE: [Throws up his Ladder, which falls down again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Humph, I see what kind of Challenge it is now; a Man must have a rare fighting Stomach, that will scale the Win∣dow of his Antagonist.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Here, here, Senior, the Coast is clear, come in at the Door boldly, my Lady is all Impatience to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Mine is the greatest; in, in my Dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: [Sings.] Ah, put her in mind how her time steals on—Oh, Charles, the Devil a Second did you want; that was only a sham to get rid of me. Ha, ha, ha, how comically things jump in my way? I'll secure the Ladder tho' for him; this is a great House, but whose it is, is the Query? If I thought I shou'd not have my Bones broke, I wou'd make bold to Enquire—Who
SP.STAGE: Enter behind him Don Perriera, and Don Lopez.
SP.P:
have we here? They seem in deep Consultation—Oh bless me,
one of them is the Bloody-minded Spaniard, egad it is not safe to be seen.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: I have done all you order'd me to a tittle, and have taken leave of my Wife for three Days, under pretence of Busi∣ness at St. Ubes.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P: That's well I can't find who this Villain is, but I warrant we shall have him fast enough. Now do you return, and cunningly convey your self into the Antichamber-closet, there lye conceal'd, he'll not be long absent, if he's not there already; in the mean time I'll wait in the Street, with two or three trusty Fellows, that shall dispatch him if he falls in our way.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: And if I find my self a Cuckold, fire, blood and brimstone, if I catch 'em, I'll send them both to the Devil.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Mercy upon me, what an Oath was that? Why certainly, they think Murder a venial Sin here, and make no more of kil∣ling a Man, then cracking a Nut. This is certainly Charles which they threaten, for the old Cacademon is gone into that House; which way shall I give Charles notice of his danger? I have a good mind to cry our Fire; ay, but when they find there is no such thing, they may burn me perhaps—Hark, I hear some Body coming, 'gad I shall be beat again.

My Fear hears double, I think, I can see no Body—Od I'll make use of this Ladder; he talk'd her Appartment was over the Door, so that perhaps I may give him warning at the Window, and he may come down the same way—Oh lord, which is the House, now? Is it this, or this, I wonder; choke me if I can tell what a blundering Sot was I not to take better notice, this must be it certainly, [Seems to throw up the Ladder between the Scenes, and Exit.] Heav'n send me good luck, for I tremble horridly.

HEAD.STAGE: SCENE draws and discovers Marron's Apartment.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Nay this is starving a Man in the sight of Plenty; how many times have you put me off with Excuses and fair Promises▪

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: And how often have you sworn Constancy, Colonel?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Why you won't give me leave to be constant, my Dear; let me once possess, and then.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: And then Mademoisel Joneton's Charms will be suffici∣ent to excuse the Perjury.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Ha! how does she know my Pretensions there? I fancy I shall have warmer business by and by than I expected. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Be not surpriz'd at my knowledge of that Affair, nor apprehensive of the least danger, tho' I know you love her, spight of all her Affectation, she's the darling Mistress of your Soul, yet you are safe, I scorn those poor Revenges which my Sex too of∣ten take; 'tis the Heart, not the Life, I'd make my Prize.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Generously said,—But you are misinform'd, Madam. I'll carry it off if possible—She's handsome, and I don't find my Love to the other renders me incapable of a Compliment to this. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: She has too much Vanity, Colonel, to keep your Passion a Secret, and it is dishonourable in you to deny your Love.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Humph! Look you, Madam, I am a true Protestant, and have a mortal Antipathy to Confession; I bear the Queen's Com∣mission, and will entertain all that will fairly list under me; then let me have no more of these little Jealousies; I'll make as good Provision for thee as for any Lady in Portugal, so prithee let's come to a right Understanding; if thou art plagu'd with an old superannuated Husband, who wants a young Fellow to aid and assist him, here he stands; if thou'rt a Widow, and wants one to ma∣nage the Affairs of Love, I'll give you my word you can't have a better; I'm an Arithmetician, as well as a Soldier, and can cast Account as fast as any Man: And if thou'rt a Virgin, Egad I'm as good an Engineer. [Embracing her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: You have mistaken your Plan, and may raise the Siege, Colonel, for you'll ne'er carry the Town this way; I own I love you, and if I said with more Sincerity than she, I fancy I shou'd not injure her Passion; my Birth's as noble, my Fortune not less; you give me some Proofs indeed, that my Person falls short of her Charms to engage the Heart of Colonel Ravelin.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Thy Person? thy Person is a charming Person, and my Heart, and all the rest of the Appurtenances, are at thy Service, my Dear; thy Birth and Fortune are things indifferent, so no more to be said about them. [Hugging her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: Will you marry me then?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Ah! what a Turn's there? Who cou'd have thought, after thy manner of proceeding, thou wou'dst have ask'd such Security; why thou art an Usurer in Love, but prithee use a Conscience; don't expect a Man to be a Slave all his life. Marriage! why what confounded Extortion is that! ods heart thou art more mercena∣ry than an Agent; look ye, Madam, I'll give you Heart for Heart, and I think that good lawful Int'rest, and thou shalt have my Body for performance of Articles.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: Ah, Colonel, you'll bring a Habeas Corpus, and remove it as soon as the Campaign begins. I don't like these Prisoners at large.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: And great Souls hate Restraint.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I have him faith—ah, how close they are, Egad, it grieves me to part 'em—but there is no help for't—Fly, Charles, fly, there's the Devil and all of Plots against you—here, here, give me your hand, come this way thro' the Window.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: Oh! a Man at my Window! oh! my Reputation is un∣done for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: How's that? a Man?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: The Devil! the Colonel!—Zounds, I am certainly be∣witch'd—I, I, I, had as good faln into the Hands of Turks and Tartars. O Lord, O Lord, my Ladder is gone, what shall I do now?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Mar-plot. S'death you Son of a Whore, I'll make an Ex∣ample of you, to all inquisitive Rascals in the Universe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ah, Colonel, for Heav'ns sake save my Life; upon my Soul you'll make me break my Neck, for I hang only by my Hands; may I be slic'd into Collops, if I knew any thing of your being here; certainly I am the most unfortunate Fellow breath∣ing.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Zounds come down Sirrah, and cease your bawling, or I'll shoot you thro' the Head.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Oh, oh, oh, I will, I will, I will, dear Colonel,

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: runs to Marton.] For Heav'n sake, Madam, don't be frighted! 'tis an honest foolish Fellow of my Acquaintance, there's no danger of your Reputation, my Angel.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: What Noise was that? ha! what do I see? My Sister and the Colonel? ah, ah!

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Confusion! she here? I'm betray'd: What, ho, within there.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: Ha! my Sister! nay then I'm compleatly wretch∣ed. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Nay, now we shall be murder'd—Oh Lord, what do you mean by calling out, Colonel?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: S'death, what did you mean, Rascal, by coming here? This Mischief is all owing to you. I have a good mind to cut your Throat. [Runs to Marton.] Madam, Madam; ods heart was ever Man in this condition? What shall I do between 'em? Run Sirrah, and call some Body.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Lord, Colonel, have a little Patience; see, see, she re∣vives.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Is this your Reservedness, this your Modesty, this your hating Mankind, Sister?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: How's that, her Sister? I have made a fine piece of work, Faith: Rascal, I cou'd find in my Heart to beat your Eyes out.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Look ye, Colonel, be merciful, and if I don't bring all this business off clear, I'll forfeit my Neck, that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Hang your Contrivance; nothing prospers you have a Hand in.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: You have decent Inclinations for a Nun; you had a mind for a taste of the World before you left it, Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: The World—the World is surfeited with your Imperti∣nence, and I wou'd avoid tasting what may breed a feaver.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Why, what an Inundation of Mistresses has this Colo∣nel? [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: If he is so good a Physician, how comes yours to rage so high, Madam? Methinks you are delirious—

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: It wou'd not be amiss to confirm your Opinion—
SP.STAGE: [Goes to strike her a Box on the Ear, but Col. Ravelin stops her Hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Hold, hold, hold, Madam; for Heav'ns sake, Ladies, let's have no Petticoat War.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ay! See what Example does, Colonel; Egad, Boxing's as catching as the Small-Pox—Nay, pray Madam let it go round—od if I were a Woman, I cou'd Box titely, but a pox on these Swords, they Spitchcock a Man in a Moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: Did not your Temper carry a Punishment in its self, I should return the Favour you design'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Shou'd! And won't you Madam? Egad, I'd fain see them pull one anothers Coifes.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Dog, mischievous Toad.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Oh your most humble Servant, Colonel—I wish your Toes were not quite so Complaisant. Their Intriegues tumble comically in my way—But egad, I pay a tragical price for my Knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Whatever Face this Accident may wear, Madam, give me leave to clear my self—upon Honour—I have not—

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Cease your odious Excuses, in vain you endeavour to be well with me—and the civillest Action you can do, is to quit the Room—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: That we shall immediately Madam; upon my Soul, it was no design of ours to come into it, for to be plain with you Ladies, I am only in fault, and yet not in fault neither, for you must know that I luckily, or unluckily, as it may fall out—

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: What, in the name of Jupiter, is he a going to say?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Chanc'd to over-hear a Quarrel between a Friend of ours and a Portuguese; the latter was foil'd in the Duel, and fled into your Neighbourhood here; but our Friend being a mettl'd Fellow, pursu'd him into the very House. Seeing that, Madam, away ran I, and call'd this Gentleman to his Assist∣ance; but finding every Door shut, and being very impatient to succour our Friend, as I told you, Madam, we resolv'd to scale the Window; but for want of taking good Notice, we mistook the House, it seems, and so happen'd in here. The Sight of two Men at the Window surpriz'd that Lady, and threw her into Fits—Compassion for the Sex made the Co∣lonel fall foul upon me—And so this created the Bustle, which brought you, Madam; an, an, an, so, so, so, an, an, that's all, Madam—Pray Heav'n this brings us off. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: Excellent Fellow! [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P:
The Dog deserves to be forgiven for this plausible Pre∣tence; I'll strike in with him—This is matter of Fact,
Ladies; yet sure there is a Fate in all I do, which guides my Steps still towards something that relates to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Well there is a Beauty in that Expression, 'twas a sur∣prizing Accident,—Can you forgive my rash Suspicions, Sister?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: And our unlucky Adventure—What induces me to hope your Pardon, is your being related to this Lady, whose good Humour cancels all Faults as soon as acknowledg'd—for her sake then.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: Ungrateful! For her sake! Methinks I hate him now, nay, hate my self for indulging a foolish Passion, equally destru∣ctive to my Ease and Fame—that has reduc'd me to this low Contempt, but with this Breath I banish the soft Passion from my Breast, and will this moment reassume my former Re∣solution.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: You seem out of Humour, Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.P: Have I not Reason, but 'tis past; the Gentleman wou'd be forgiven for your sake, but I forgive him for my own, re∣solving to let nothing ruffle that Calmness with which my Soul's possest at present, for this Day shuts me from the World and you for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What does she mean by that now? But Colonel, Charles will be kill'd—

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Hush, hush, enough, the Jest will grow stale. 'Tis pity so much Youth and Beauty should be sacrificed to a Cloyster, for if I apprehend you right, 'tis that you mean, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I wish they were both there, so that Charles was but out of Danger. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mart.
SP.L: 'Tis only there I can my Peace retrieve,
Where seeing nothing, nothing can deceive:
Shut from your sight, my Wishes I'll controul,
Imure my Body, to preserve my Soul.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Turn Nun! Who wou'd have thought it? So, there's an end of one Intreague.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Some forty years hence, perhaps, I may follow her Ex∣ample—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Upon my Soul Colonel, Charles is in danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: What do you mean? 'Sdeath I'll toss you out the same way you came in, you long to spoil all again—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P:
Spoil the Devil—I tell you, he is in one of these Houses, I saw him go in, and heard an old Cuckold swear what
he'd do if he caught him with his Wife; and then egad went into that very House. My eagerness to give Charles notice of the Danger, tumbled me a top of you, a pies on't; and tho' I have brought you off, you are for tossing me out at Window. Egad I think no Man meets such barbarous returns for his good Nature, as I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Nay, if Charles is really in Danger, I beg your Pardon with all my Heart, Mr. Mar-plot.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: What is this Consultation about? Et bein Monsieur, who are you thinking of?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Of you, Madam: Inclination and Honour holds Dis∣pute, Inclination chains me to your Presence, but Honour calls me to the rescue of my Friend: And I hope his Distress will excuse my abrupt Departure. Adieu, ma chear ange.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: And will you then precipitate your self into danger? This Gentleman will go—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: She's very charitably inclin'd towards me, I thank her. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Won't you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Why look ye Madam, I, I, I will go with all my Heart, but, but, but, but,

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: But a single Arm is weak Assistance, where the danger is so strong—besides it would be a Reflection upon mine Ho∣nour—You are my Guardian Angel, if you smile I shall re∣turn in safety.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Faith is the main Point of Religion: Pray take me in∣to your Protection too, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: So, he is gone then; now wou'd not I give a Dish of Tea for a Lover that I could not make sacrifice every thing to me. These Englishmen have too much Sense to make Hus∣bands on:

L.HI: For only he shou'd to our Sex be dear,
Who from a Look is capable of Fear.
The Man of Courage lords it every where.

HEAD.STAGE: SCENE, The Inside of Dona Perriera's House.

DIV2.STAGE: Dona Perriera and Charles at Supper, Margaritta waiting.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: I like the Description you have given me of Eng∣land extreamly, and envy the pleasant Life your Ladies live. Here's a Health to their Husbands; I wish they cou'd teach ours their Complaisance.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: We had rather teach their Wives, Madam, who have much more Docility: But here's to their Conversion.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: We! Why are you in the Number of marry'd Men?

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: I have a Breviat to act as one, Madam, in the Absence of your Husband, if it is not your Fault. Come, my Angel, we shall be interrupted again.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Why? you have no more Friends to come down the Chimney, have you?

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: If you have, I wash my Hands of him; no more De∣liverance from me, I assure him. I hate to have a Scheme baulk'd that is so well laid.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: No, no, Seniora Margaritta: What I apprehend is the Return of your Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: He's safe for three Days, which time I expect you pass with me. I have several Doubts to be resolv'd, and as many Articles to make, e'er I give my self entirely to your Power.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: What Agreements are we to make, I wonder? This In∣trigue will end very foolishly, I foresee that. [Aside.] All Secrets, I suppose. The next Room is more private, I fancy; there I'll do my Endeavour to solve your Scruples.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Margaritta, bring in the Wine.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Well thought on.
SP.L: The amorous Feast of Cupid soon wou'd cloy,
If Bacchus did not joyn the fainting Boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P:
And is it then true at last? Am I a Cuckold? Oh Vengeance! Vengeance! Oh Anthony, thou Guardian Saint of
Lisbon, give me Patience; let me have Christian Charity upon their Souls, for I shall have no Mercy upon their Bodies. I have sent for two Priests to take their Confessions, and then they die: Here I'll wait their Coming; shou'd I enter, my Eyes wou'd let loose my Revenge too soon: 'Tis enough that I have them secure, and that my Ears have heard a Man's Voice with this vile Adultress.

L.HI: But since such Pleasure in his Arms she proves,
Death shall join her unto the thing she loves.

HEAD.STAGE: SCENE changes to the Terriera de Passa.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: As I suspected, he is here in this House; thro' the Sove∣reign Power of Gold I have discover'd all; but for my Ease, wou'd I had been ignorant still. Vice, thou ugliest Picture of the Soul, by what Power dost thou charm, and lull asleep the Dictates of a Conscience? And who can boast of Honour, that starts not at the Breach of Vows? Who have we here?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Methinks I never went so heavily of an Errand in my Life: I am sorry for this Englishman, and heartily sorry for my Mistress; for, to give her her due, she is the best-natur'd Wo∣man to her Servants living: And, faith, I can't blame her for loving this Gentleman better than that old gouty, ptisicky, crook-back'd, covetous Hunks my Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Isah.
SP.P: Ha! this is the Servant which I brib'd. Of what Er∣rand is he sent? [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: What Saint shall I invoke, to save this wretched Pair? I know St. Anthony is engag'd on Don Perriera's Side—Let me see, there is some She-Saint that has been a Sinner this way her self; if I cou'd think of her Name, she'd be the fittest Person to do their Business.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Their Business! Oh, my boading Heart foretels some Mischief. Lorenzo—

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Ha! who's there?

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: 'Tis I, fear not: What is the Cause of your Com∣plaint?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Oh! is it you, Senior? Oh, your Country-man's un∣done. My Master, pretending to go to St. Ubes for three Days, conceal'd himself in the House unknown to every body, and has discover'd all. I'm sent this Moment for two Monks from the Convent of Sante Vincente to confess the Criminals, and then you know what follows.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Death! Oh Distraction! which, oh, which way, ye Powers, shall I save this perjur'd Man?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Ay, dear Sir, think, if it be possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Oh Charles! little dost thou think how dear thy un∣lawful Joys are purchas'd; three Lives for a momentary Bliss: For, in spight of all the Cause that thou hast given me, thou'rt still as dear as Virtue to my Soul, and Life without thee is not to be born. Oh, hear me Heav'n, that knows my chaste Desires, and pity the Distress that tears my Breast; instruct me how to ward this fatal Blow, and save a Man that may return to thee. Ha! methinks I feel the inspiring Thought, and Hope begins to feed the Springs of Life—Lorenzo, first bring the Priests to me. If you perform this Business with Success and Secrecy, I'll double twice this Sum.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: May I meet the Fate design'd for them, if I'm not faithful to you.

L.HI: If by this Plot I save this perjur'd Man,
I give the greatest Proof of Love that Mortal can.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Isabinda in a Ferriwig and Night-gown, and two Priests; a Sword lying upon the Table.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Priest.
SP.P: PLead not for Adultery; wou'd you have us draw a Scandal on our Function?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Priest.
SP.P: All we can do is to set the Criminals right in their Journey to the other World, Son.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P:
Oh, 'tis a long Journey, Fathers; and who shall bring you word how they arrive? Tell me, even you who purchase
Heav'n daily by your Prayer, to sell and canton out as you think fit, how wou'd you receive a Summons of this Nature? Wou'd sudden Death appear a welcome Guest?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Priest.
SP.P: The Innocent can never fear to die. Had he, for whom you plead, liv'd free from Guilt, Death wou'd appear no formidable Enemy.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Priest.
SP.P: Suffer us to discharge our Office, or we must leave you. [Going.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Oh, my tortur'd Soul! if they go, Charles is lost for ever. [Aside.] He that treads this way treads upon his Death.
SP.STAGE: [Runs and catches up the Sword, draws, and gets between them and the Door.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Priest.
SP.P: Ha! St. Vincent defend us.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Not all the Saints your Calendar can boast shall save you, except you save my Brother; your Innocence can never fear to die—

And tho' your Souls will know no Pity here, when I've dis∣charg'd 'em from those heavy Carcasses, they may prove a Con∣voy to these Strangers. You who daily trade with Heav'n, must surely know the Road.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Priest
SP.P: Hold, hold—if we thought this Matter cou'd be done with Safety, and that it was Charity to save them—

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: That it is Charity, let this demonstrate—Here's 200 Moydres to be employ'd in charitable Uses.
SP.L: Perhaps the Prayers of such whom you relieve
May pull a Blessing from offended Heav'n,
And this poor guilty Pair may find Forgiveness.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Priest.
SP.P: This is a Youth of excellent Parts.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Priest.
SP.P: A Favourite of St. Vincent's, I warrant, he's so charitable. Well, Son, seeing you so well inclin'd, we do consent, propose the way: Take care you do not expose us—

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: I'll tell you my Design within, 'tis free from Hazard, or may the Punishment design'd for them be mine. I'll follow you, Fathers.

L.HI: O'er all Degrees of Men Gold bears a Sway,
Where all Entreaties fail, Gold finds the way;
Be thou propitious, Heav'n, and bless the Scheme I lay.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: What a cursed while this Rascal stays; if he comes not instantly my Rage will get the better of my Reason, and I shall dispatch the foul Adulterers without Confession.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Lorenzo, and Isabinda in Priests Habit, and one of the Priests with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I have obey'd your Orders, Senior, here are the Priests.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: But very slowly, Hang-dog.

SP.SPEAKER: Priest.
SP.P: Peace be to you, Son.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: That's not your Business, Father; try if you can administer Peace to my salacious Wife and her young Amouretta within there; but do you hear, Fathers? Dispatch the Busi∣ness of their Souls as speedily as I will that of their Bodies: But if Heav'n has no more Mercy than I shall have, your La∣bours might have been spar'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Priest.
SP.P: Speak not so irreligiously—Which is the Room? Keep your distance.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Per.
SP.P: Make haste then, or I shall take your Work out of your Hands. Now let me consult my instruments of Death, for I'll have no bounds in my Revenge. I'll, I'll, I'll, flea 'em alive.

HEAD.STAGE: Scene draws and discovers Dona Perriera and Charles.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Is it the unreasonableness of my Request, or the smallness of your Respect, that causes this Hesitation, Senior? Sure if I give my self intirely to your Arms, I may deserve to be freed from the Embraces of a Wretch I hate. I'll not be chargea∣ble to you in my Passage, I have Jewels of considerable Value to defray that Expence; I insist upon a Promise, that you will convey me to England, and then I am yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Why then to deal ingeniously, Madam, I am married in England, and shan't well know how to bestow you there—But whilst I am here, Child, I am thine—

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Ah! Maria mater, dic ora pro nobis, [Crossing her self.] Oh, we're undone, this hour is our last.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Laying his Hand on his Sword.] Ha! What are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Priest.
SP.P: Our Habits show what we are, and your Guilt what you have need of.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Priests! Nay, then our condition is worse than I ex∣pected.
SP.STAGE: [Don Per. Runs and falls on her Knees.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Oh, confess me streight, my Soul is taking flight already; I see a thousand dire revengeful Fiends hovering o'er me, and watching all to catch it in the Air. Oh save it Father by your Holy Prayers, for in you only all my Comforts center.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Come Son, consider the great Work you have to do, Death waits without, therefore examine your self within.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: The Work must be all my own, Father, I have no occa∣sion for a Journey-man, so you may spare your Pains.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: How, a Heretick! alas poor Soul, how much it troubles me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Pray good Father express your trouble some where else, I have no Faith in your living Doctrine, and resolve to have nothing to do with you in Death, therefore don't trouble me—Is there no way to escape, and must I die cowardly? No, that I will not, [Draws] the first that enters dies; I'll have Com∣pany at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: A weak Defence, alas, shou'd I desert him—Put up your Sword, in pity to your Ignorance, and in hopes of Con∣verting you to the true Faith, I'll deliver you from this hazard.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: But can you save her too?

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: How Son! Is this a time to dream of future Pleasures?

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: I'll give you mine Honour, Father, never to see her more; but as I am Partner in the Guilt, I wou'd not have the Punish∣ment be only hers.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Well, I'll endeavour to preserve her too; observe my Orders well, turn your Face, here put on this Garment, my Brother there will conduct you to a place of safety, where I de∣sire you'll wait till I come; look not behind you, nor speak as you pass the Husband of that Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: This Priest is an honest Fellow, [Puts on the Cloaths.] nothing like the Habit of Sanctity to cover close Designs, I shall observe your Directions most religiously, Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Priest.
SP.P: Come Son, your Hand—Madam, I leave you one to comfort your Distress.

HEAD.STAGE: [Scene shuts, then draws and discovers Don Perreira Lissening.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: How still they are at Confession, I fancy the Pe∣nance I shall enjoin them, will quicken their Voice. So,
So your parts are done then, Fathers? Now for mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Priest.
SP.P: Done! I'm afraid Son, you are not right in your Senses, you have given us the trouble of coming to confess two Adul∣terers, you said, but how you can make two Women such; I leave to you, for there is no Male thing in the Room by my Priesthood; take care you put no more Affronts upon our Cloth.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Women! I'm amaz'd! Women! Egad I'm ravish'd, transported, nay, translated methinks above the Stars; I'm, I'm, I'm, I'm, od I know not what I am, I'm so glad to find my self no Cuckold—Ah, but how shall I look my Wife in the Face tho', for having blam'd her wrongfully? Ay, there's the Devil now—Pox take her Brother for instilling these Jealousies into my Head, I fear she will never forgive me—and indeed 'tis more than I deserve—Oh, that ever I should suspect her Virtue.

HEAD.STAGE: The Scene draws and discovers Dona Perriera on her Knees to Isabinda.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona.
SP.P: Oh Madam, you have set Vice and Virtue in their proper Light, from whence I see the Deformity of one, and Beauty of the other; your generous Forgiveness is all I want, to raise my Soul above a second fall. I have injur'd you, but—

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: No more of that; the good Inclination which you show wipes out all faults with me, and your Perseverance will give you as large a share in my Breast, as if you never had offended. Rise Madam, I hear the Door unlock, prepare your Husband according to my direction, and leave the rest to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Ay, there they are—both Woman by St. An∣thony—that ever I should be such a Dunce to think my self a Cuckold—Which way shall I speak to her now? Oh, my poor dear innocent Lamb is all in Tears, nay thou hast cause to weep, that is the truth on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: What have I done, my Dear, that you shou'd ex∣pose me thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: That thou hast done nothing at all to merit it, is my grief—Nay do not weep, thou wilt break my Heart, indeed thou wilt; I wish with all my Soul thou hadst Cuckolded me; I think in my Conscience I cou'd forgive thee now.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: What Reparation can you ever make me, for the stain you have cast upon my Fame, expos'd me to the Priests, cou'd you have found no other way?

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: I was to blame indeed, Wife; oh forgive me, [falls on his Knees.] or my Heart will burst: Oh, oh, oh, oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Nay, now, Madam, you must forgive him.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Ay do, dear Madam, intercede for me; I'll never rise, except my dear virtuous Spouse will say she pardon me.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Don Lopez with his Sword drawn.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P: What! Hangman like, are you asking Pardon e'er you dispatch her? I'll lend you a helping hand, since you are not Master of your Resolution.
SP.STAGE: [Don Per. rises hastily, and catches down a Blunderbuss and cocks it at Don Lopez.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Zounds, put up your Sword, or by St. Anthony I'll shoot you through the Head.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Do you start, Brother? Cou'd you inflict that on me which your own Courage starts at? Cruel Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: A Brother shou'd rather reconcile, than blow the Coals of strife; 'tis barbarous in Strangers, but much more so in those ally'd to us by Blood: Revenge, tho' just, excludes Religion, and he that pursues it poisons all his Morals, and impudently affronts that Power which gave him Breath to threaten.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P: Hie day, what Philosopher have we here?

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Out of my Lodgings, I say, without one question more, and never set foot into them again, as you hope to keep your Guts in▪ I'll be plagu'd with no more of your Jealousies, I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Lop.
SP.P:
Fine! your Lodgings!—but hear me, Don, dare not for your Soul, say you match'd into my Family, or you Mistress boast of any Blood of mine, as you value those Eyes—for from
this day I hold you as a Bastard, and may Perdition seize you both.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Was ever Man so plagu'd?—Come, dry thy Eyes, my Dear, and mind him not, I'm glad I'm rid of him—and if thou dost but forgive me now, by this I'll ne'er offend again.
SP.STAGE: [Crosses his Thumb and Finger, and kisses it.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Then I am happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Pray Wife, who is this Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Heav'ns! what shall I say now? [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: Hold, Madam,—Let me intreat your Presence, with your Lady's, in my Apartment, which is directly under this, and that you wou'd suspend you Curiosity 'till that time.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: This is certainly an Angel in disguise.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: We'll wait on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Here's Mademoisel Joneton to wait on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Bring her up.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: I'll take my leave, and shall expect you with impa∣tience.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: The desire of knowing how to treat you as I ought, Madam, will give me Wings to follow you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: My Dear, I'm glad to see you—Oh Senior, are you there? Pray when do you intend to return to your House? Will it never be finish'd? It is enough to Murder one to come up thus high—Positively I'm as much out of Breath as a Trumpeter. Ah pest, it has given me a Colour like a Cook-Maid.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Thou art more impertinent than a Valet de Chambre. My House will be finish'd next Week, Madam, and then 'tis to be hop'd these Disorders which you complain of will cease.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Very probable they may—I am horridly chagreen'd to Day, my Dear, I have made twenty Visits within this hour, and can meet with no Conversation to my Gout; the Vanity of the Men gives me the Spleen, and the Insipidness of the Women makes me sleepy—I came just now from my Lady Betty Trifle's, where I set the whole Room a yawning; ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Impertinence—A Person of your polite Conver∣sation, must not expect to be diverted every where: How does your Sister, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Oh my Sister is this day dead, my Dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: How! Dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: How! Dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Metaphorically speaking, she has enclos'd herself, where she intends to mortifie with Hymns, and spiritual Songs, and has left me the whole World to range in.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: And I warrant you think that but a Garden.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: If the Sea cou'd be drain'd, 'twou'd make a very pretty Park, Senior.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Humph! This is a Woman of a copious Fancy—Well my Dear, I'll go before you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Not for the World—Madam, if you please, since you are upon the visiting Pin, I'll introduce you to a new Ac∣quaintance—I'd rather take her with me, than suffer him to go without me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: With all Satisfaction, I love new Acquaintance extremely, is it a Man?

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: No; a Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: What has she to recommend her?—But, no matter, I'll wait on you. The Devil take this Colonel, I can't get him out of my Head, I am half afraid I indure him more than I imagin'd. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: Madam, will you give me leave to wait on you down?

HEAD.STAGE: The SCENE draws and discovers Charles solus, in Isa∣binda's Appartment looking about him.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: What will be the issue of this Affair, Heav'n knows. To what end am I order'd to stay here, under the same Roof? And why is this Priest so long a coming? My Mind misgives me, it was no Priest—But some Rival, jealous of her Favours, found the way to surprise us, and contrary to the Custom of a Portu∣guese, has Honour enough to dispute it with me fairly; faith I wish that may be the worst on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Egad, here he is—Charles, I'm glad to find thee alive with all my Blood—

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: The Devil! Ha! Colonel Ravelin there too? You sur∣prise me? How did you find me?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: By Mar-plot's Direction, you know he's a very good finder, he assur'd me you wanted my Assistance—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ah Charles, which got the better in the Duel, Ha? What Weapons did you fight with?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: I can't tell what Engagement thou hast been in, Charles, but by thy Looks, I fancy it has not pleas'd thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: I have run some hazard since I saw you, Colonel, but if I had caught you dogging me, I'd a hamstring'd you, Rascal—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Very fine—See what a Man gets for his good will now—But if I had not thought you in danger of Hamstringing, and Heartstringing too; the Devil a step wou'd I a fetch'd. I'm sure the old Cuckold frighted me out of my Wits with his threats, and the Colonel here has almost broke my Bones, and all for you—And thus you reward me—

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: The old Cuckold! What do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Nay, let the Colonel tell you what I mean, for my part I'll have nothing to do with you as long as I live again—Bless me, what do I see? The very old Dog that swore by Fire, Blood and Brimstone, he wou'd send you to the Devil—Oh Lord, oh Lord, draw Gentlemen, draw, put your self upon your Guard, Charles, oh dear Colonel stand by him; ods life I trem∣ble so, I cannot get my Sword out for my Blood—

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Ha! What are you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Get you behind me, you timerous Puppy.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: What do you mean, Gentlemen, to murder me?

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: I mean that you shan't murder me, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: You, Sir? why I don't know you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Not know him, Sir, what a confounded lying old Thief you are, I'll take my Oath I heard you and that bloody-minded Spaniard, threaten what you'd do to this Gentleman, if you catch'd him in your House; egad Charles, knock him down.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Oh Mr. Sweep-chimney, are you here? St. Anthony defend me, what Ambuscade am I tumbled into? This was cer∣tainly my Wife's Gallant, and has impos'd upon the Priests, as well as me, in Petticoats, and now has trapan'd me here to murder me—Help, Murder, Treason, Murder, help—

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Taking him by the Collar.] Cease your bawling, old Luci∣fer, or expect no Mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Confess your design, and produce your villainous Gang, and they shall have Satisfaction, equal to their Merits.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Gang? By St. Anthony, I have no Gang; I came hi∣ther to wait on the Lady who belongs to this Appartment, but little thought of meeting with my damnable virtuous Wife's Gal∣lant. I suppose I am decoy'd hither to have my Throat cut, there∣fore come on both of you, old as I am, I yet can stand a Push.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Oh, oh, Murder, Murder, Murder.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: I wish I had known you in Petticoats.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Ha, this must be Don Perriera; but what does he mean by Petticoats? Hold, Sir—What is the Lady's Name of this Appartment?

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: I know not, it was to be inform'd of that I came, but I suppose you are the Lady, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: This shallow-brain'd Whelp has made a damn'd blunder here—This is a very odd Riddle, Sir, pray—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ah! a Ghost, a Ghost, a Ghost—

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: St. Anthony defend me, a Ghost? where?
SP.STAGE: Enter Isabinda, Dona Perriera, Mademoisel and Margaritta.
SP.P: Oh, Madam, is it you? This is the Lady I came to wait on, Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Ha! She here!

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: That Lady, in the Habit of a Priest, delivered you—Do you know her?

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Know her! Yes—Delivered by my Wife—

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: The Colonel here too? I'm not displeas'd with this Visit. [Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: My Mistress—a pretty kind of a Rencounter.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Oh let me fly into thy Arms, my Isabinda, my charm∣ing Love, thou holdest more Virtues in thy Breast, than thy whole bst▪ Can'st thou forgive me, Isabinda?

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: As freely as thou can'st ask it; but hush, we shall be ob∣serv'd; let not the Company know this is our first meeting. I was loath to trust the Writings with Strangers, so brought them my self.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Thou are all Goodness.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: I thought I heard Murder cry out as I enter'd, Senior.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Why truly, Madam, if you had not come as you did, I was in danger of my Life here.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: 'Twas only a Mistake, my Dear. I ask your Pardon, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Pardon, Sir? This is a very odd mistake, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Egad, and so it is; a Pox of my Zeal—

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.P: I hope all Mistakes will be clear'd, Sir, I know you loved my Father, Sir, Jealous Traffick; and for his sake, I hope you'll know my Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: What, my old Friend? Yes faith will I, Sir, I am yours, but I must kiss your Wife. My Dear, why did not you tell me who she was before?

SP.SPEAKER: Dona Per.
SP.P: A good Reason, because I did not know. [Aside.] You saw she forbad me, my Dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Now you are all acquainted, I'll tell you how I came to mistake this Matter: I did not know this was a House of Lodgings, nor that my Friend had remov'd hither, till I found him out by Accident, upon my Honour, Senior—

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: The Rogue will stumble out an Excuse.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Honour! Pray, Sir, upon your Honour tell me how you got out of my Room?

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: For your Soul, no squeaking— [Aside to Mar-plot.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: No, no; never fear me. Egad, what shall I say now? Why, Sir, you must know I am a Chimist, and have found out a Secret that will open and shut all Locks whatever; that help'd me out, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Say you so, Sir? Pray will you communicate.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Not for your whole Estate, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: I'll have this Fellow sent out of Town, for by the help of this Secret he'll Cuckold all the Men in Lisbon.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, what a Lie has he lit of—Colonel, won't the Lady capitulate upon Honourable Terms?

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: She desires two days Consideration, a great while for a Man to fast, that is almost starv'd already.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Well, Colonel, to shew you I am good-natur'd, I'll put it to Arbitration.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.P: Nay, then Madam, we shall all give it against you.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: What's here, a Wedding on foot? Prithee let's have it just now, to reconcile all Differences, and tho' I have not danc'd these forty Years, will take a turn among you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: So! I'll be hang'd if this is not Mademoisel Flutter now. Pox of these Matrimonial Intreagues—but Egad we will have Dan∣cing—I'm resolv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: Faith, Madam, the Cannon of Constancy is a heavy Car∣riage, and if I shou'd summon my Senses to a Council of War, and make Reason Judge-Advocate, 'tis odds but I raise the Siege.

SP.SPEAKER: Mad.
SP.P: Well, Colonel, if I surrender Prisoner of War, remem∣ber I expect to be generously us'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Rav.
SP.P: You shall have no cause to complain.

SP.SPEAKER: Om.
SP.P: We wish you Joy, Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Don Per.
SP.P: Now for a Dance.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: And I have brought the Musick.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.L: Come, Colonel, Marriage is the only happy
State, when Virtue is the Guide.
Had but all Women Isabinda's Mind,
So Constant, Prudent, Virtuous, and so kind,
What Joys so great as Wedlock cou'd we find?
No more shou'd we unlawful Love pursue,
But think our Wives for ever young and new,
And learn from them the Art of being true.

SP.SPEAKER: Isab.
SP.L: In vain we strive by haughty ways to prove
Our chast Affections, and our duteous Love.
To smooth the Husband's rugged Storms of Life,
Is the design and business of a Wife;
Still all his Faults with Patience to behold,
And not for ev'ry Trifle rant, and scold:
Men from Example, more than Precept, learn,
And modest Carriage still has power to Charm.
After my Method, wou'd all Wives but move,
They'd soon regain, and keep their Husbands Love:
Our kind Indulgence wou'd their Vice o'ercome,
And with our Meekness strike their Passions dumb.

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE.
DIV1.L: THE Play concluded, I'm at last set free,
Resume my self, and now am Cap-a-pee,
A free-born Nymph of English Liberty.
I sweat t' have been a Wife but three bare Hours;
What is't to be one then for Life, ye Powers,
Where Husbands too are ten times worse than ours?
The slightest Trip with them demands our Blood;
But venial Frailties here are better understood.
Your Don Cornuted is a Monster there,
But thank our Stars, the Fate's no Wonder here.
The Monster ceases, where the Case is common,
And watch your Eyes out, you must trust the Woman.
In vain her Person with Restraint you load,
When Spite of Walls her willing Mind's abroad.
A blessed Life indeed! where churlish Fear
Attends the Thing your Appetites cou'd spare.
Is there on Earth, a Wretch, a greater Jest,
Than the pale Lover, starv'd for Beauty's Feast,
That begs, in pity of his famish'd Sense, a Taste?
Protest his Appetite shall last for Ages,

Incurable his Pain, and laugh'd at in Distress,
He snarling cries, Consume my Happiness.
Oh, tiresome Plenty! O intollerable Bliss!
Oh the lost Joys of freeborn Wretchedness!
Like Dog in Manger, thus he snarles and bites,
And curses what another's Taste delights.
While such Examples 'fore my Eyes I see,
Guard me, ye Powers, from Loss of Liberty.
'Tis strange, you Britains, whom no Force can humble,
Shou'd court those Chains, at which you're sure to grumble:
But since, alas! 'tis fatal to the Age,
I'll ev'n maintain my Post upon the Stage;
Which (for at once I'd all Mens Hope prevent)
I'll never leave, tho' tempted with a Settlement.
